gen.conclusions: A metal-only wideband folded patch antenna for CubeSat applications is demonstrated, achieving a wide bandwidth, high gain, and good efficiency. The measurement results show good agreement with simulation results (p. 11)

gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The fabricated prototype achieves a −10 dB bandwidth of 44.9% (1.6–2.7 GHz), a small reflection coefficient of −24.4 dB, and a high efficiency of 85% at 2.45 GHz (p. 1); The efficiency of the proposed antenna fluctuates between 82% and 88% from 2.2 GHz to 3.7 GHz (p. 11); The peak realized gain is 8.5 dBi with cross polarization level less than −20 dB at 2.45 GHz and a 3 dB gain bandwidth of 61.22% (p. 1); Not mentioned; The proposed antenna has a maximum gain of 8.5 dBi at 2.45 GHz (p. 10); The proposed antenna achieves a measured |S11| < −10 dB bandwidth of 1.6–2.7 GHz (44.9%) (p. 10)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The optimal parameters for the antenna include W1 = 22.8 mm, L2 = 15.6 mm, and W3 = 15.6 mm (p. 4); The proposed antenna has a high radiation efficiency of 85% at 2.45 GHz (p. 11); Not mentioned; The proposed antenna has a 3 dB gain bandwidth of 61.22% (p. 11)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna addresses the bandwidth limitation of patch antennas while maintaining a compact size and high efficiency. The use of shorting pins and folded patch feeding techniques significantly improves the bandwidth and gain (p. 2)

gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The measured impedance bandwidth of the second design is about 1.68% where the center frequency is about 2.443 GHz (p. 5); Measured percentage impedance bandwidths were 2% and 1.68%, respectively (p. 1); Maximum gain of about 5 dBic around the target frequency (p. 1); The bandwidth of the prototyped antenna (Design 1) has been measured to be about 2% where the center frequency is about 2.44 GHz (p. 5); The obtained maximum gain is about 5.02 dBic (p. 5); The obtained maximum gain is 5.8 dBic (p. 5); Two designs were implemented on two different substrates, occupying footprints of 38 mm × 38 mm and 30 mm × 30 mm (p. 1)

gen.conclusions: The metamaterial-inspired meander line antenna design successfully achieves a compact size and high performance, making it suitable for CubeSat communication systems. The antenna can be integrated with 2U CubeSat structures and onboard subsystems (p. 1)

gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The peak resonance was tuned at 450 MHz (p. 7); The antenna achieved a −10 dB impedance bandwidth from 435.5 to 461 MHz (p. 7); The antenna showed a gain of 2.5 dB and 69% radiation efficiency when integrated with the CubeSat structure (p. 9); The fabricated antenna operates within the lower UHF frequency band of 443.5–455 MHz with an average peak gain of 2.5 dB (p. 1); The free space path loss (FSPL) at 400 km orbital altitude was 137.9 dB (p. 9); The antenna size is 80 × 40 × 3.35 mm³, fitting within the 2U CubeSat body (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The antenna's impedance stability was explored after integration with the 2U CubeSat body layout (p. 1); The antenna communication performance was verified using 2U CubeSat free space path loss investigation (p. 1); The proposed antenna outperformed other designs in terms of size, gain, and efficiency (p. 10)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna design addresses the challenges of size and performance in CubeSat communication systems by utilizing a metamaterial-inspired meander line structure. The antenna's compact size and enhanced performance make it suitable for integration with 2U CubeSat structures (p. 1)

gen.conclusions: The proposed 2×2 FSP antenna array is a viable solution for small satellites, offering dual-band and dual-circularly polarized radiation in a compact form factor. It can support various communication and positioning functions while meeting the size constraints of CubeSats and picosatellites (p. 1)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Comparison of simulation and measurement results (p. 5)

gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Experimental design with simulation and measurement (p. 4)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The design achieves dual-band operation and dual-circularly polarized radiation using meandering, folding, and shorting techniques (p. 1); The antenna array has a compact size of 50 mm × 50 mm (p. 1); The antenna array achieved good agreement between simulation and measurement results (p. 5); The proposed 2×2 FSP antenna array operates at 1.1 GHz and 2.4 GHz with dual-circularly polarized radiation (p. 1); For the upper band, the realized gain maximum was about 2 dBic at 2.3 GHz (p. 4); For the lower band, the realized gain maximum was about 0 dBic at 1.1 GHz (p. 4)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The cross-polarization level is more than 25 dB below the main broadside beam maximum for CP1 and about 18 dB below for CP2 at the upper band (p. 5); The axial ratio (AR) was determined to be less than 3 dB for the lower band and less than 1 dB for the higher frequency band over a 40° beam angular range (p. 5); The antenna array can support S-band downlinks and multiple transmitting and receiving functions for communications and positioning (p. 1); The design is more compact and uses fewer elements compared to other similar designs (p. 2); The cross-polarization level is about 15 dB below the main broadside beam maximum for CP1 and CP2 at the lower band (p. 5)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna array is suitable for simultaneous L-Band and S-band operation on CubeSats, picosatellites, and other small satellite structures, offering dual circular polarization (DCP) functionality. The lower band is suitable for low data rate communications and telemetry, while the upper band is useful for downlinks and ground station communications (p. 5)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The design is specific to picosatellites and CubeSats and may not be directly applicable to other satellite types (p. 1); limitation_type: Fabrication tolerances | description: A slight downward shift in the operating frequencies due to practical fabrication tolerances (p. 5)

gen.conclusions: The proposed algorithm is effective for synthesizing beam patterns in DRAs, particularly in multi-beam scenarios with constraints. It provides a framework for dimensioning, design, and beamforming of DRAs, applicable to various satellite and ground-based systems (p. 13)

gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The algorithm effectively distributes activation instances in multi-beam scenarios (p. 10); The algorithm meets the required beam pattern specifications and ensures a uniform activation distribution across the antenna array (p. 1); Array thinning reduced the number of active elements while maintaining desired beam properties (p. 8); The algorithm prevents saturation in central antenna elements (p. 13); Not mentioned; The algorithm successfully optimized beamwidth and SLL for multiple beams in a CubeSat scenario (p. 8)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: Central elements of the array were more frequently activated in multibeam scenarios (p. 8); Mutual coupling between adjacent unit cells remains below −20 dB (p. 4); Beamwidth error shows minimal variation in the first two scenarios but increases in the third scenario (p. 11); Shifting active elements in the array maintained beam integrity while reducing activation frequency (p. 8); Total gain and EIRP show a downward trend due to array thinning (p. 11); Not mentioned; SLL values approach their limits as more activation instances are allowed (p. 11)
gen.discussion: The algorithm's capability to evenly distribute activation instances and prevent saturation in central elements is a key finding. The approach is versatile and can be adapted to different platforms and frequency bands (p. 13)

gen.conclusions: The proposed compact tri-band omnidirectional antenna for 1U CubeSat applications offers stable performance across UHF, L, and S-bands, high radiation efficiency, and a fully enclosed structure, making it an ideal solution for next-generation low-cost, high-performance CubeSat communication systems (p. 14)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Comparison of simulated and experimental results to validate the antenna performance (p. 1)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Anechoic chamber for experimental validation (p. 1); CST Microwave Studio for simulation (p. 2); Not mentioned; CST simulations for design optimization (p. 9); Vector network analyzer for S-parameters (p. 10); Anechoic chamber for radiation pattern measurements (p. 10)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and optimization of a compact tri-band omnidirectional antenna using CST Microwave Studio (p. 2)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The antenna operates at UHF (0.755 GHz), L-band (1.25 GHz), and S-band (2.28–3.74 GHz) (p. 1); The antenna exhibits omnidirectional radiation patterns across all frequency bands (p. 1); The antenna exhibits high radiation efficiency (above 90%) at all resonance frequencies (p. 14); The measured radiation efficiency exceeds 90% (p. 1); The antenna is fully enclosed within the CubeSat, eliminating the need for external deployment (p. 14); The proposed antenna achieves multi-band resonance at UHF, L, and S-bands (p. 14); The antenna dimensions are 100 × 100 × 101 mm³ (p. 2); Not mentioned
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: Not mentioned; The design uses a defected ground structure (DGS) and metallic vias to enhance impedance matching (p. 1); The antenna offers better bandwidth, higher radiation efficiency, and a more compact form factor compared to existing CubeSat antennas (p. 14); The antenna is fully enclosed within the CubeSat, ensuring easy integration and mechanical robustness (p. 1)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna design offers a novel approach with enhanced stability, compact size, and ease of deployment within a CubeSat. The innovative use of metallic vias and a defected ground structure contributes to the antenna’s unique ability to achieve multi-band resonance while maintaining an omnidirectional radiation pattern. The compact dimensions and lightweight nature due to 3D-printed plastic CubeSat prototyping maximize space efficiency within the CubeSat, allowing ample room for additional components (p. 2)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The design is specific to 1U CubeSats and may not be directly applicable to larger CubeSat configurations (p. 2); limitation_type: Material properties | description: The use of PLA plastic for the CubeSat may introduce additional effects on the antenna's performance (p. 8); limitation_type: Not mentioned | description: Not mentioned

gen.conclusions: This work represents part of a project aimed at designing and realizing a microstrip patch antenna adapted to the missions and dimensions of a CubeSat, in which we have focused on increasing the gain that represents a very important parameter. The simulation results showed that increasing the number of radiating elements affects positively the antenna gain and that the rectangular shape has better performances in terms of gain compared to the triangular shape. (p. 7)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Simulation results analyzed for gain, return loss, radiation pattern, and other performance metrics (p. 2)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Not mentioned; ANSYS® High Frequency Structure Simulator (HFSS) version 2020-R2 (p. 2)
gen.detailed_methodology.population_cont: S-band microstrip patch antennas for CubeSats (p. 2)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Comparative simulation study (pp. 2-3)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The gain increased significantly with the number of radiating elements, with the rectangular shape having an advantage (p. 3); The 2×2 rectangular antenna array achieves a gain of 13.18 dB, while the 2×2 triangular antenna array achieves a gain of 11.78 dB (p. 3); The rectangular antenna has an advantage in terms of gain compared to the triangular one, for all the configurations carried out, namely, single element, 2×1 array and 2×2 array. (p. 7)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: Not mentioned; The triangular 2×1 array model achieved the best return loss performance with -45.97 dB at 2.3225 GHz (p. 5)
gen.discussion: The rectangular shape provides higher gain compared to the triangular shape, and the gain increases with the number of radiating elements. The results suggest that rectangular arrays are more suitable for high-gain applications in CubeSats (pp. 3-5)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Simulation | description: The study is based on simulation results and may not fully represent real-world performance (p. 5); limitation_type: Not mentioned | description: Not mentioned

gen.conclusions: The use of the flower pollination algorithm (FPA) and the angular-inset feed technique can effectively optimize the design of microstrip patch antennas for CubeSat communications, achieving good performance in terms of return loss, gain, and impedance matching (p. 4)

gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The antenna has an impedance bandwidth of more than 96 MHz (| S11| < -10 dB) (p. 5); The maximum gain of the single element antenna was 7.33 dB at the resonance frequency (p. 4); The S11 parameter was -27.9663 dB at 2.5447 GHz, indicating good matching (p. 5); The designed 2x1 microstrip antenna array achieved a gain of 9.06 dB at 2.5447 GHz (p. 5); The optimized circular patch antenna achieved a resonant frequency of 2.56108 GHz with a return loss of -27.1167 dB (p. 4)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The antenna outperforms other designs in terms of gain and return loss while meeting size requirements (p. 5); The -10 dB impedance bandwidth of the single element antenna was more than 70 MHz (p. 4); The Half-Power Beam Width (HPBW) was 70.81° (p. 5)
gen.discussion: The optimized design using FPA and the angular-inset feed technique significantly improved the performance of the microstrip patch antenna, making it suitable for CubeSat applications (p. 4)

gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The peak gain is 5.82 dBic at UHF band and 13.75 dBic at C-band (p. 1); The antenna has a common bandwidth of 1% and 1.4% for UHF and C-band, respectively (p. 1); The frequency ratio is 6.4 (p. 1); The proposed antenna has an impedance bandwidth of 3.9% (894–930 MHz) and 9.9% (5.75–6.35 GHz) at UHF and C-band, respectively (p. 5); Axial ratios less than 3 dB from 909 to 918 MHz at UHF band and from 5.72 to 5.80 GHz at C-band (p. 5); Peak gains of 5.82 dBic at 912 MHz and 13.75 dBic at 5.82 GHz (p. 5)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The antenna radiates circularly polarized waves with right-hand circular polarization at 912 MHz and left-hand circular polarization at 5.75 GHz (p. 5); Front-to-back ratio of 7 dB at 912 MHz (p. 5); The antenna has an isolation higher than 35 and 20 dB at UHF and C-band, respectively (p. 1); The antenna has a unidirectional radiation pattern (p. 5)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna design is suitable for 1U CubeSat systems due to its compact size and large frequency ratio. It outperforms other designs in terms of bandwidth, gain, and polarization (p. 6)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The design is specific to 1U CubeSat and may not be directly applicable to other satellite sizes (p. 1); limitation_type: Platform size | description: The small platform of the 1U CubeSat limits the front-to-back ratio (p. 5)

gen.conclusions: The proposed antenna design, leveraging Minkowski fractal geometry and RF-MEMS switches, is an excellent candidate for small satellites and CubeSats due to its compact footprint, structural simplicity, and low manufacturing cost (p. 1)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Comparison of simulated and measured data for reflection coefficient (S11) and radiation patterns (p. 6)

gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and simulation of a reconfigurable Minkowski fractal antenna (pp. 2-3)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The antenna can be operated efficiently at both distinct frequency bands by activating or deactivating MEMS switches (p. 7); The reconfiguration mechanism allows for dynamic tuning without mechanical alteration (p. 4); The antenna operates effectively in the 1 GHz and 4 GHz frequency bands (p. 4); The antenna exhibits robust performance across both frequency bands, confirming its effectiveness and reliability in reconfigurable wireless systems (p. 7)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The antenna maintains stable and symmetric radiation patterns despite the inclusion of RF-MEMS devices (p. 7); The antenna exhibits consistent directional behavior in both configurations (p. 5)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna design offers significant advantages in terms of size reduction and functional flexibility, making it particularly suitable for satellite communication systems, such as CubeSats (p. 7)

gen.metadata.title: Design of high performances electronically reconfigurable antenna arrays by means of parasitic structures and RF-MEMS switches
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and analyze a dual-band patch antenna that leverages the reconfigurability of Minkowski fractal geometry and RF-MEMS switches to achieve frequency agility (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Evaluate the antenna's performance at both frequency bands (p. 7); Optimize the antenna to operate in the 1 GHz and 4 GHz frequency bands (p. 1); Demonstrate the antenna's reconfigurability and adaptability (p. 7); Validate the performance through full-wave electromagnetic simulations (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Not mentioned; Explore the application of this design in other frequency bands and satellite platforms (p. 2)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; Integrate RF-MEMS technology in future antenna designs for improved reliability and precision (p. 2)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Traditional phased array antennas and other reconfigurable radiating structures are unsuitable for CubeSats due to their excessive physical size, high implementation costs, and complexity of control systems (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can fractal geometries be used to achieve compact and multifunctional radiating elements for small satellites? (p. 1); What are the benefits of integrating RF-MEMS switches for dynamic frequency reconfiguration in fractal antennas? (p. 2); What are the performance benefits of using fractal geometry in reconfigurable antennas? (p. 7); How can RF-MEMS switches be used to reconfigure the resonant frequency of a patch antenna? (p. 7)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Evolutionary algorithm within Advanced Design System (ADS) by Keysight Technologies (p. 4)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_softwa: Advanced Design System (ADS) by Keysight Technologies (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Not mentioned
esp.domain_results.gain: 3.5 dBi at 1 GHz, 3.1 dBi at 4 GHz (p. 7)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Consistent directional behavior in both configurations (p. 5)
esp.domain_results.return_loss: Low S11 parameter, indicating good impedance matching (p. 4)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Dual-band patch antenna with Minkowski fractal geometry (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Microstrip line with width w0 = 0.4 mm (p. 4)

gen.conclusions: The proposed high-gain, broadband, circularly polarized FPC antenna with SSSA excitation is a promising solution for high-data-rate communication in CubeSat applications. The antenna's simple structure and high performance make it suitable for integration with small satellite platforms (p. 1)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Comparison of simulated and measured results, performance metrics evaluation (p. 8)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Anechoic chamber for pattern measurement (p. 8); Agilent PNA network analyzer E8364C for S11 measurement (p. 8); CST Microwave Studio for simulation (p. 8); Simulation software (Altair FEKO) (p. 12); Anechoic chamber for measurement (p. 3); Simulation software (Altair FEKO) (p. 2); Anechoic chamber for measurement (p. 12)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Experimental and simulation-based (pp. 8-9)
gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design and simulation of a high-gain, broadband, circularly polarized FPC antenna (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: Measured peak realized gain of 15.73 dBic (p. 8); The gain variation over the bandwidth is less than 1.3 dBic (p. 1); The axial ratio bandwidth was 6% (p. 12); When mounted on a CubeSat body, the measured gain increased to 16.83 dBic (p. 9); The VSWR bandwidth was [8.36, 8.58, 8.75, 9.49] GHz (p. 12); The fabricated prototype antenna provides right-hand circular polarization with a peak measured gain of 15.73 dBic over a common bandwidth of 1.03 GHz ranging from 7.99 GHz to 9.02 GHz (p. 1); The antenna achieved a gain of 14 dBic (p. 12); The bandwidth was 1.0 GHz (p. 12); The return loss was −31.3 dB (p. 12); When integrated with the metallic body of a 1U CubeSat, the simulated gain of the antenna increases to 17.23 dBic, with a peak measured gain of 16.83 dBic (p. 1); The cross-polarization level was −25 dB (p. 12); The antenna achieved a 1.03 GHz common bandwidth from 7.99 GHz to 9.02 GHz (p. 8)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: Side lobe level below -10 dB at 9 GHz (p. 8); The antenna measures 80 mm × 80 mm × 21.14 mm and is simple, lightweight, and easily integrable with CubeSat body (p. 1); A deployment method is proposed for this antenna that results in a total stowed volume of only 2.13λo × 2.13λo × 0.084λo (0.38 λo) (p. 1); X-Pol level below -16 dB in the broadside direction (p. 8); The antenna outperformed other designs in S11 bandwidth, SLL, gain, cross-polarization level, and size (p. 12); AR below 3 dB over the band (p. 8)
gen.discussion: The concept of SSSA excitation in FPC antennas allows for independent control of polarization at different frequencies, resulting in a large overall bandwidth and high gain with a simple structure. This makes the antenna suitable for high-data-rate communication in CubeSat applications (pp. 1-4)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The design is specific to 1U CubeSats and may not be directly applicable to larger satellite platforms (p. 1); limitation_type: Size | description: The antenna height is approximately 0.5λo, which is large for smaller CubeSats (size < 2U) (p. 8); limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study is limited to a specific design and may not be directly applicable to all CubeSat missions (p. 12)
gen.metadata.keywords: superstrate antenna; circular polarization; circularly polarized; FPC antenna; high gain; high-gain; Fabry Perot cavity; CubeSat; SSSA excitation; X-band; broadband
gen.metadata.authors: Ananjan Basu; M.P.A.; Ratul De; A.B.; Mahesh P. Abegaonkar; Not mentioned; R.D.
gen.metadata.title: A broadband circularly polarized Fabry Perot antenna with spatially separated superstrate area excitation for CubeSat applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To develop a high-gain, broadband, circularly polarized Fabry–Perot cavity (FPC) antenna for high-data-rate communication in CubeSat applications using the concept of spatially separated superstrate area (SSSA) excitation (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Integrate the antenna with a 1U CubeSat chassis and demonstrate a space-saving deployment mechanism (p. 1); Simulate the antenna performance using appropriate software (p. 12); Fabricate the antenna prototype (p. 12); Achieve a large overall bandwidth and high gain with a simple structure (p. 1); Achieve a broadband CP performance (p. 8); Design a deployable mechanism to save space on smaller CubeSats (p. 8); Design a high-gain, compact, and lightweight X-band superstrate antenna (p. 12); Design and validate the concept of SSSA excitation in FPC antennas (p. 1); Measure the antenna performance in an anechoic chamber (p. 12); Enhance gain over the operating band (p. 8)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the antenna in different CubeSat missions and environments (p. 1); Investigation of other frequency bands and antenna configurations (p. 12); Further optimize the superstrate patch size to improve AR performance (p. 9); Explore the application of SSSA excitation in other types of antennas for CubeSat applications (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the antenna with 1U CubeSat chassis using the proposed deployment mechanism (p. 1); Further testing in space environments (p. 12); Utilize the antenna for high-data-rate communication in CubeSat applications (p. 1); Use the proposed antenna for high data-rate downlinks in CubeSat applications (p. 9)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing high-gain, broadband, circularly polarized antennas for high-data-rate communication in CubeSat applications, while addressing the constraints of small platform size and limited pointing accuracy (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a high-gain, compact, and lightweight X-band superstrate antenna be designed for CubeSat applications? (p. 12); What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna and how does it compare to other designs? (p. 1); How can SSSA excitation be used to achieve broadband and high gain in FPC antennas for CubeSats? (p. 8); How can the gain and axial ratio bandwidth of a conventional narrowband circularly polarized source patch antenna be increased using spatially separated superstrate area (SSSA) excitation? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 12)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms other designs in S11 bandwidth, SLL, gain, cross-polarization level, and size (p. 12)
esp.domain_results.gain: 15.73 dBic standalone, 16.83 dBic when installed on 1U CubeSat (p. 8)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: 6.84% of a 1U CubeSat's top face (10 × 10 cm²) (p. 12)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: High-gain, broadband, circularly polarized Fabry–Perot cavity (FPC) antenna (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT Duroid 5880 (εr = 2.2, tan δ = 0.001, h = 1.57 mm) (p. 8)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: CP single-feed hexagonal-shaped patch with a slot (p. 12)
l = 9.9 mm, s = 7 mm, w = 0.8 mm, fx = 2.6 mm, fy = 1.4 mm, L = 80 mm (p. 6)
esp.technical_specifications.superstrate: Single square dielectric with square metallic patches of different sizes printed on both sides (p. 3)
Central patches: w1 = 8.2 mm, w2 = 9.4 mm; Outer patches: w1 = 9.6 mm, w2 = 8.4 mm, p = 11 mm, g = 10.6 mm (p. 9)

gen.conclusions: The developed design procedure for a dual-polarized ultra-wideband ACMA is effective and suitable for CubeSat applications, achieving the required performance metrics while minimizing construction complexity and costs (p. 1)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Optimization using sequential non-linear programming (SNLP) in Ansys HFSS (p. 3)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Multi-probe system Starlab and other microwave facilities at MVG Italia for measurements (p. 8); Anechoic chamber for measurements (p. 9); Ansys HFSS for simulation (p. 3); Simulation software (Altair FEKO) (p. 11)
gen.detailed_methodology.population_cont: CubeSat applications, specifically for an agile polarimetric radar at Ka-band (p. 1)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Constrained cross-optimization of different geometric parameters (p. 11)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: H/V isolation was greater than 30 dB over the entire matching band (p. 6); The optimized ACMA achieved a fractional bandwidth of about 50% (2.8–4.71 GHz) for both polarizations, with a return loss ≥10 dB (p. 6); The co-polar gain of the proposed antenna is between 7 and 10.3 dBi (8.1 and 10.9 dBi), with 3.3 dB (2.8 dB) variation for the H port (V port) (p. 9); The measured H/V isolation is almost always greater than 30 dB, except in the initial part of the band below 3 GHz, where it reaches 25 dB (p. 9); The measured efficiency is between 0.85–0.98 (0.78–0.997) for the H port (V port) (p. 9); The bandwidth is almost equal to the simulation, with a slight shift upwards of 100 MHz (2.91–4.81 GHz) (p. 9); The cross-polar gain of the proposed antenna is always less than −13 dBi for both polarizations (p. 9)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: Good agreement between simulations and measurements was obtained (p. 8); Good agreement between simulation and measurement results was achieved (p. 9)
gen.discussion: The design procedure utilizes a constrained cross-optimization of different geometric parameters, making the antenna suitable for cost-effective mass production and space applications such as low-cost CubeSats (p. 11)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The design is specific to CubeSat applications and may not be directly applicable to other contexts (p. 1); limitation_type: Manufacturing imperfections | description: Possible loss of symmetry of antenna geometry due to manufacturing imperfections and measurement tolerance (p. 9); limitation_type: Material properties | description: PLA losses, which are not perfectly known, could adversely affect the gain (p. 9)
gen.metadata.keywords: high polarization isolation; high polarization purity; ultra-wideband antenna; patch antenna; dual polarization antenna; ultra-wideband; dual-polarized; CubeSat; aperture-coupled microstrip antenna
gen.metadata.authors: DiCarlofelice, A.; E.D.; A.D.; P.T.; DiGiampaolo, E.; Tognolatti, P.
gen.metadata.title: A Numerical Procedure to Design a UWB Aperture-Coupled Microstrip Antenna Suitable for Space Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To develop a design procedure for a dual-polarized ultra-wideband ACMA suitable for CubeSat applications, with a focus on minimizing construction complexity and costs (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve good agreement between simulation and measurement results (p. 11); Develop a simple layered structure without inter-layer interconnects (p. 11); Ensure the design is suitable for large-scale production by minimizing construction complexity (p. 1); Design an ACMA with a fractional bandwidth > 40%, return loss > 10 dB, and polarization purity and isolation > 25 dB (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Further investigation into the impact of manufacturing imperfections and material properties (p. 9); Explore the use of different materials and manufacturing techniques to further optimize performance and cost (p. 1); Investigate the application of the design procedure to other frequency bands (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the developed design procedure for creating ACMA for CubeSat applications (p. 1); Consider the use of simple multilayer structures without interlayer interconnections or inclusions to minimize costs (p. 1); Use the design procedure for cost-effective mass production of antennae for CubeSats (p. 11)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a dual-polarized ultra-wideband aperture-coupled microstrip antenna (ACMA) suitable for CubeSat Ka-band applications, with a focus on minimizing construction complexity and costs (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a dual-polarized ultra-wideband ACMA be designed for CubeSat applications with minimal construction complexity and cost? (p. 1); What design procedure can achieve the required performance metrics (fractional bandwidth > 40%, return loss > 10 dB, polarization purity and isolation > 25 dB) using simple technology? (p. 1); How can a simple layered structure without inter-layer interconnects be developed for dual-polarized ultra-wideband aperture-coupled microstrip antennae? (p. 11)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: 11.9 m × 5.6 m × 6.0 m anechoic chamber using the multi-probe system Starlab and other microwave facilities at MVG Italia (p. 8)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Ansys HFSS optimizer using sequential non-linear programming (SNLP) (p. 3)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Not mentioned
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Dual-polarized ultra-wideband aperture-coupled microstrip antenna (ACMA) (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT6002 (ϵr = 2.94, tanδ = 0.0012) for dielectric 1, RO4003 (ϵr = 3.55, tanδ = 0.0021) for dielectrics 2 and 3 (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.substrate_m: Rogers RT6002 for dielectric 1, RO4003 for dielectrics 2 and 3 (p. 5)

gen.conclusions: The design of an isoflux phased array for Cubesats has been successfully demonstrated, showing that high-frequency designs allow for compact mounting suitable for use on the 1U Cubesat face (p. 2)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Genetic algorithm optimization, full-wave simulation using CST Microwave Studio (p. 2)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Genetic algorithm (GA) for optimization (p. 1); CST Microwave Studio for full-wave simulation (p. 2)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Optimization using a genetic algorithm (GA) and full-wave simulation (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The optimized array configuration includes two concentric rings with 5 and 10 elements, respectively, and no central element (p. 2); The array achieves a 2.3dB ripple across ±25° and 0.55dB ripple across ±20° (p. 2); The maximum directivity of the array is nearly constant from 10.8 to 11.6GHz at approximately 11.5dB (p. 2)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The CP bandwidth is limited by the broadside field, with CP obtained from approximately 10.9GHz to 11.18GHz, yielding 280MHz bandwidth (p. 2)
gen.discussion: The design of an isoflux phased array for Cubesats is feasible and allows for compact mounting on the 1U face. The array meets gain mask requirements and can be optimized further to improve radiation performance (p. 2)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Simulation | description: The study is based on simulation results and may require experimental validation (p. 2)
gen.metadata.keywords: isoflux; Cubesat; phased array; optimization
gen.metadata.authors: Joseph E. Diener; Robert D. Jones; Atef Z. Elsherbeni
gen.metadata.title: Isoflux Phased Array Design for Cubesats
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and optimize a compact isoflux phased array for Cubesats using a genetic algorithm (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Optimize the array configuration to fit on the 1U face of a Cubesat (p. 1); Achieve a near-isoflux power pattern on the Earth’s surface (p. 1); Demonstrate the array’s performance using full-wave simulation (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Experimental validation of the optimized array design (p. 2)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Further optimization considering mutual coupling effects (p. 2)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing a compact isoflux phased array for Cubesats in low Earth orbit (LEO) to enable effective communication over a large portion of the Earth’s surface (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a genetic algorithm be used to optimize the design of a phased array for Cubesats? (p. 1); What are the performance metrics of the optimized isoflux phased array? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Genetic algorithm (GA) and full-wave simulation (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Not mentioned
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: 3D radiation pattern with a maximum at 17° and a 2.7dB roll off by 25° (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: Fits on the 1U face of a Cubesat (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Microstrip patch phased array (p. 1)

gen.conclusions: The optimized RMPA-PE covers a candidate bandwidth for X-band CubeSats and two other bandwidths suitable for Ku-band CubeSats systems with a maximum gain of 7.80 dB and directivity of 7.88 dBi at 8.2 GHz (p. 4)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Performance analysis using return loss, VSWR, gain, and directivity (p. 3)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: ANSYS HFSS for initial design and optimization (p. 2); CST MWS for re-simulation (p. 3)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Genetic Algorithm (GA) optimization (p. 2)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The optimized RMPA-PE covers X and Ku bands with resonant frequencies at 8.23 GHz, 13.96 GHz, and 15.14 GHz (p. 4); The antenna achieves a unidirectional radiation pattern, a gain of 7.80 dB, and a directivity of 7.88 dBi at 8.2 GHz (p. 3)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The first band (8.16 GHz to 8.31 GHz) is suitable for X-band CubeSats (p. 4); The second band (13.40 GHz to 14.3 GHz) is suitable for Ku-band CubeSats (p. 4); The third band (14.91 GHz to 15.43 GHz) is suitable for passive EES/SRS applications in Ku-band CubeSats (p. 4)
gen.discussion: The parasitic patch method combined with GA is a potential method for optimizing MPA’s radiating performances for miniaturized satellites (CubeSats) communications (p. 3)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Simulation | description: The results are based on simulation and may differ in practical implementation (p. 3)
gen.metadata.keywords: MPA; Parasitic element; CubeSat; Genetic Algorithm; X/Ku bands; ANSYS HFSS
gen.metadata.authors: Mohamed El Bakkali; Najiba El Amrani El Idrissi; Faisel Em Tubbal; Gurjot Singh Gaba
gen.metadata.title: Optimum design of a tri-band MPA with parasitic elements for CubeSat communications using Genetic Algorithm
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and optimize a tri-band MPA-PE for X and Ku bands CubeSat communications using Genetic Algorithm (GA) (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Optimize the dimensions and positions of the parasitic elements, slot dimensions, and feed line dimensions (p. 2); Achieve a compact size and high performance suitable for CubeSat applications (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Further research should aim at utilizing GA optimization technique to improve the performance of the developed antenna and its array of different shapes and configurations (p. 4)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Utilize GA optimization technique to further improve the performance of the developed antenna and its array of different shapes and configurations (p. 4)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for compact, lightweight, and high-performance antennas for CubeSat communications, particularly in X and Ku bands (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can the performance of a microstrip patch antenna (MPA) with parasitic elements (MPA-PE) be optimized for X and Ku bands CubeSat applications using Genetic Algorithm (GA)? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Genetic Algorithm (GA) optimization using ANSYS HFSS and CST MWS (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.bandwidth: First band: 8.16 GHz to 8.31 GHz, Second band: 13.40 GHz to 14.3 GHz, Third band: 14.91 GHz to 15.43 GHz (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Not mentioned
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Tri-band microstrip patch antenna with parasitic elements (RMPA-PE) (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: RT Duroid 5880 (εr = 2.2, tan δ = 0.001, h = 0.8 mm) (p. 2)

gen.conclusions: The proposed RMPA-PE design with parasitic elements is a viable solution for high gain, compact, and low-cost antennas for CubeSat inter-swarm communications. The design is validated through simulation and experimental results (p. 10)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Genetic Algorithm Optimization (GAO) for parameter optimization, simulation using ANSYS HFSS, and experimental measurements using VNA (p. 6)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Simulation using HFSS (p. 1); Measurement using VNA (p. 1); ANSYS HFSS for simulation (p. 5); Vector Network Analyzer (VNA) for experimental verification (p. 10)
gen.detailed_methodology.population_cont: 3U Cube satellite under development by University of Wollongong, Australia (p. 5)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and optimization of a Microstrip Patch Antenna (MPA) with parasitic elements using ANSYS HFSS and Genetic Algorithm Optimization (GAO) (p. 3)
gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design and optimization of a rectangular patch antenna with parasitic elements (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The optimized antenna achieved an enhanced gain of 7.2 dBi, ultra-wideband of 5750 MHz (25.35 –31.19 GHz), and a high return loss (RL) at the targeting frequency of 28.7 GHz (p. 1); Measured and simulated results show that the constructed antenna has a RL well below 10 dB at 28.7 GHz (p. 15); The optimized RMPA-PE achieved a large bandwidth of 5750 MHz, peak gain of 7.2 dB, and RL of 22.22 dB at 28.7 GHz (p. 15); The experimental results confirm that the optimized antenna gives a RL of 18.0 dB and a suitable impedance BW for Inter-Swarm communications (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The parasitic element dimensions were optimized using GAO (p. 15); The use of parasitic elements significantly improves the total gain from 4.7 to 7.16 dBi (p. 7); The optimized value of the parasitic element width (We) is 1.26 mm, achieving an RL of 22.22 dB and Ultra-Wide bandwidth of 5.75 GHz (25.35 –31.10 GHz) (p. 7)
gen.discussion: The use of parasitic elements in the MPA design significantly enhances the gain and bandwidth without increasing the physical size, making it suitable for CubeSat applications. The results are validated through both simulation and experimental measurements (p. 7)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study is specific to a 3U Cube satellite under development by University of Wollongong, Australia, and may not be directly applicable to other CubeSat designs (p. 5); limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study is specific to the 28.7 GHz frequency and may not be directly applicable to other frequencies (p. 15)
gen.metadata.keywords: 28 GHz; parasitic element; small satellite; Return Loss (RL); Parasitic Element (PE); CubeSats; ANSYS HFSS; High gain antenna; rectangular patch antenna; CubeSat; Microstrip Patch Antenna (MPA); Genetic Algorithm Optimization (GAO)
gen.metadata.authors: El Gholb, Y.; El Idrissi, N.A.; Gaba, G. S.; El Bakkali, M.; Mounssef, A.; Kansal, L.; Tubbal, F.; El Amrani El Idrissi, N.; Tabakh, I.
gen.metadata.title: Analysis and Optimization of a Very Compact MPA with Parasitic Elements for Inter-swarm of CubeSats Communications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a very compact Microstrip Patch Antenna (MPA) with parasitic elements for Inter-Swarm of CubeSats communications, providing communication links between the swarm’s CubeSats at LEO (p. 3)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a compact size, low-cost, high gain, and large beamwidth angles (p. 3); Evaluate the performance of the optimized antenna at 28.7 GHz (p. 1); Enhance the gain of the MPA without increasing its size or changing its materials (p. 3); Optimize the dimensions of the parasitic element to enhance the antenna's gain and bandwidth (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Explore the use of other optimization techniques for antenna design (p. 10); Investigate the impact of different parasitic element configurations on antenna performance (p. 10); Investigation of the antenna's performance at other frequencies and in different CubeSat configurations (p. 15)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the optimized RMPA-PE design for CubeSat inter-swarm communications (p. 10); Consider the use of parasitic elements to enhance antenna performance in other CubeSat applications (p. 10); Further testing and validation in real CubeSat environments (p. 15)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Limited power, size, and weight restrictions of CubeSats pose big challenges to any CubeSat communication system designers, especially when moving from S-band, C-Band to X-band or Ka-band, which requires high gain antenna with small size (p. 3)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What is the impact of using parasitic elements on the performance of the MPA for CubeSat communications? (p. 3); How can the gain of a Microstrip Patch Antenna (MPA) be enhanced without increasing its size or changing its materials? (p. 3); How can the gain and bandwidth of a rectangular patch antenna be improved for CubeSat applications? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Finite Element Method (FEM) using ANSYS HFSS (p. 5)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms other designs in terms of gain, bandwidth, and size (p. 4)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Rectangular Microstrip Patch Antenna (RMPA) with parasitic elements (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Rectangular radiating element and a strip feed line (p. 5)

gen.conclusions: The proposed low-profile MPA with parasitic elements is a viable solution for CubeSat communications, offering high gain and wide bandwidth at X and Ku bands (p. 3)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Simulation results analyzed for gain, directivity, return loss, and bandwidth (p. 3)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: HFSS 13.0 and CST MWS 2017 simulators (p. 3); Not mentioned
gen.detailed_methodology.population_cont: 3U CubeSat under development by University of Wollongong, Australia (p. 3)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Simulation and optimization using HFSS and CST MWS (p. 3)

gen.conclusions: A wideband MPA for 5G CubeSat’s applications is demonstrated. A wide −10-dB impedance bandwidth is achieved by using a parasitic element, leading to the generation of a second operating frequency and improved impedance bandwidth. 21 slots are loaded to the main radiating patch to improve the proposed patch antenna’s gain. The proposed antenna provides a wide measured −10-dB bandwidth of 20.2%, a small measured reflection coefficient of −45 dB, and a measured gain of 6.9 dB at 28 GHz. Measurement results show good agreement with simulation results (p. 52)

gen.conclusions: A compact wideband CP microstrip antenna array for next-generation small satellite applications in the Ku-band was successfully designed, simulated, and fabricated. The array achieved a measured peak gain of 15.5 dBic and met the performance requirements for gain and AR in the angular width from −10° to +10° (p. 10)

gen.conclusions: The paper presented a novel design of a hybrid patch/spiral antenna. The antenna consists of four concentric rectangular patches with a spiral internal antenna. The proposed antenna is characterised by its compact size, lightweight, low cost, and at the same time, covers multi bands that fulfil L, S, C, X, Ku, K, and Ka bands. The antenna is suitable for CubeSat applications. Thanks to the low coupling between antennas, it is easier to design both antennas separately. The performance of the antenna is more reliable as its two subsystems do not affect each other, and it is a versatile design. The measured and simulated results reveal accepted coincidences with each other. (p. 13)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Comparison of simulated and measured results using CST and Vector Network Analyzer (p. 8)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Vector Network Analyzer (Agilent E8363B) (p. 8); In-house made anechoic chamber (p. 8); CST simulation software (p. 8); Not mentioned; Simulation software (p. 2)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and simulation of a hybrid spiral/patch antenna (pp. 1-2)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The antenna achieves a gain of 4-10 dBi (p. 1); The antenna efficiently achieves the 3 dB axial ratio (AR) in both simulation and measurement (p. 9); The proposed antenna covers L, S, C, X, Ku, K, and Ka bands (p. 1); The reflection coefficients (S11 and S22) achieve < -10 dB (p. 1); The antenna achieves −10 dB impedance at the bandwidth 1.5–2.9 GHz for the patch antenna and 4–31 GHz for the spiral antenna (p. 8); Not mentioned; The axial ratio achieves < 3 dB (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The coupling between two ports 1 and 2 (S12 and S21) is < −20 dB (p. 8); The antenna weight does not exceed 1.33 kg (p. 1); Not mentioned; The antenna fits within the standard 10 × 10 cm² size of a CubeSat (p. 1); The front-to-back ratio (F/B ratio) is more than 5 dB (p. 10)
gen.discussion: The proposed hybrid internal spiral/patch antenna meets the radiation requirements of circular polarization and is suitable for CubeSat applications due to its compact size and performance across multiple frequency bands (pp. 10-11)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The design is specific to CubeSat applications and may not be directly applicable to other satellite types (p. 1); limitation_type: Size | description: The proposed antenna is a planar design that takes minimum space and does not need a deployment mechanism, but it may not achieve the same performance as larger, non-planar designs (p. 10); limitation_type: Not mentioned | description: Not mentioned

gen.conclusions: The study presented the design and testing of a dual-frequency left-hand circular polarization patch antenna array for the 3Cat-5/A satellite. The antenna met some but not all requirements, and it was used successfully in the FSSCat mission (p. 9)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Measurement of S11 parameter, radiation pattern, gain, and axial ratio (p. 9)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Numerical simulations (p. 2); CST Studio Suite for simulations (p. 4); Thermal vacuum chamber (TVAC) (p. 8); Theoretical analysis (p. 2); Prototyping (p. 2); Anechoic chamber (p. 9); Vector Network Analyzer (VNA) for combiner measurements (p. 7); UPC Antenna Lab Anechoic Chamber for measurements (p. 5); Environmental testing (p. 1); Vector Network Analyzer (VNA) (p. 9)
gen.detailed_methodology.population_cont: 3Cat-5/A satellite, part of the FSSCat mission (p. 8)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Theoretical analysis, numerical simulations, prototyping, and environmental testing (p. 1)
gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design and validation of a custom antenna (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The designed antenna meets the directivity, polarization, and return loss requirements (p. 1); Combiner was designed and characterized, showing significant differences between simulations and measurements (p. 7); The S11 parameter and radiation pattern were measured before and after TVAC testing (p. 8); Single-frequency circular polarization antennas were successfully simulated and prototyped (p. 5); Dual-frequency circular polarization antenna stack was designed and simulated (p. 5); The GPS L1 band results were not compliant with all requirements, while the MWR band complied in terms of directivity and axial ratio (p. 9); The antenna was tested in a TVAC with two thermal cycles between +80°C and -20°C (p. 8); The antenna fits within the specified envelope and weight constraints (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The antenna design includes a 3 by 2 array of six elements, each a stacked dual-band patch antenna (p. 3); The combiner showed inconsistencies due to M2.5 interface holes (p. 7); The air gap between the MWR and GPS L1 antennas reduced efficiency in the L1 band and increased axial ratio (p. 9); The dual-frequency antenna stack met the requirements for RL in the MWR band and GPS L1 (p. 7); The antenna is composed of four printed circuit boards (PCBs) (p. 3)
gen.discussion: The design and testing process identified issues with manufacturing tolerances and dielectric constant variations, which affected the antenna's performance. Despite these issues, the antenna was successfully used in the FSSCat mission for soil moisture, sea ice concentration, and sea salinity retrieval (p. 9)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Design constraints | description: The antenna must fit within a 300 mm × 200 mm × 7 mm envelope and withstand extreme temperature changes (p. 1); limitation_type: Simulation and Measurement Discrepancies | description: Significant differences between simulation and measurement results for the combiner, likely due to M2.5 interface holes (p. 7); limitation_type: Manufacturing Tolerances | description: Manufacturing tolerances and dielectric constant variations affected the antenna's performance (p. 9); limitation_type: Time Constraints | description: Due to the mission schedule, it was not feasible to perform another iteration to address the non-compliance issues (p. 9)

gen.detailed_results.main_findings: Maintained an ARBW of 1.97–2.31 GHz (15.8%) (p. 17); Achieves a stable gain of approximately 7.50 dBic at 2.025 GHz (p. 1); The antenna achieved a wide impedance bandwidth (IBW) of 1.65–2.70 GHz (50%) in stand-alone configuration (p. 14); The realized gain was approximately 7.50 dBic at 2.025 GHz (p. 7); The antenna maintained circular polarization (AR < 3 dB) over 1.97–2.32 GHz (p. 14); The fabricated prototype achieves a wide impedance bandwidth from 1.65 GHz to 2.70 GHz, fully encompassing the CubeSat uplink (2.025–2.110 GHz) and downlink (2.200–2.290 GHz) frequency ranges (p. 1); Maintains an axial ratio below 3 dB across 1.97 GHz to 2.32 GHz, ensuring efficient circular polarization (p. 1); The maximum realized gain was approximately 7.50 dBic (p. 14); Unidirectional radiation patterns with HPBW of 56°–73° and F/B ratios up to 13.53 dB (p. 17); Stable realized gain of 5.99–7.50 dBic across the operating band (p. 17); Not mentioned; Achieved an IBW of 1.65–2.70 GHz (49%) (p. 17); The sixth-generation antenna design achieved a wide IBW of 1.65–2.70 GHz and an ARBW of 1.97–2.32 GHz (p. 7)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: Outperformed existing designs in terms of IBW, ARBW, gain, and compactness (p. 17); The optimal arc width (𝐿𝑃2) of the parasitic patch was 24 mm, achieving the best impedance matching and AR (p. 8); The antenna exhibited stable radiation efficiency and total efficiency, approaching 99% (p. 14); The optimal arc length (𝑊𝑃3) of the parasitic patch was 49.5 mm, achieving a wide IBW and stable AR (p. 8); The combination of compact structure, low profile, and wideband circular polarization makes the proposed antenna a promising candidate for CubeSat communication systems (p. 1); Not mentioned; The optimal truncation length (𝑊𝑃2) was 18 mm, achieving an IBW of 1.65–2.70 GHz and a maximum gain of 7.50 dBic (p. 8); The optimal slit-ring diameter (𝐷𝑇) was 2 mm, achieving a wide IBW and stable AR (p. 8); The antenna demonstrated unidirectional radiation patterns with HPBW of 56°–73° and F/B ratios up to 13.5 dB (p. 14); The optimal inter-substrate spacing was 14.3 mm, achieving the best impedance matching and AR (p. 9)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna design effectively meets the stringent performance requirements of CubeSat communication systems by integrating wide IBW, strong circular polarization, stable gain, and unidirectional radiation patterns into a compact form factor (p. 17)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study focuses on a specific frequency band and design, which may limit its applicability to other frequency bands or different CubeSat configurations (p. 1); limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study is limited to the S-band and specific CubeSat applications (p. 8); limitation_type: Integration effects | description: The CubeSat-mounted configuration exhibited a narrower IBW due to chassis-induced currents and frame loading (p. 14); limitation_type: Generalizability | description: Performance may vary in different CubeSat configurations and environments (p. 17); limitation_type: Not mentioned | description: Not mentioned

gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Ensure stable realized gain of 5.99–7.50 dBic across the operating band (p. 17); Incorporate corner truncations, a slit-ring structure, and symmetrically positioned segment-circular parasitic patches to enhance impedance matching and polarization performance (p. 1); Maintain stable circular polarization with an axial ratio bandwidth (ARBW) of 1.97–2.31 GHz (15.8%) (p. 17); Implement a vertical capacitive feed through a dual-stacked RT/duroid® 5880 substrate to improve current distribution and broaden the operational bandwidth (p. 1); Achieve a wide impedance bandwidth (IBW) of 1.65–2.70 GHz (49%) (p. 17); Not mentioned; Optimize the antenna design for maximum performance in the S-band (p. 5); Evaluate the impact of parasitic patches on bandwidth and circular polarization (p. 5); Evaluate the antenna's performance in a CubeSat environment (p. 10); Design a compact antenna with dimensions of 0.72𝜆0 × 0.72𝜆0 × 0.13𝜆0 at 2.150 GHz (p. 17); Optimize the antenna dimensions and configurations for maximum gain and bandwidth (p. 10); Maintain unidirectional radiation patterns with favorable HPBW and F/B ratios (p. 17)

gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Conventional planar microstrip patch antennas generally exhibit narrow impedance bandwidth (IBW) and axial ratio bandwidth (ARBW), due to their high quality factor (Q), which compromises their suitability for CubeSat missions that demand stable circular polarization performance across wide frequency ranges and varying incident angles (p. 1)

gen.conclusions: The Sierpinski gasket fractal antenna is a viable solution for low-earth orbit CubeSat applications, offering better performance compared to conventional UHF antennas. Future research should explore optimized results for other patch geometries (p. 11)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Simulation results and field test measurements (p. 6)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: HFSS FEM method for electromagnetic structures software (p. 2); Radiation pattern results (p. 11); Reflection coefficient and VSWR measurements (p. 11); Radio anechoic chamber for field tests (p. 6)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and simulation of a fractal antenna, followed by experimental validation (p. 11)
gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design and performance evaluation of a fractal antenna (p. 2)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The proposed fractal antenna resonates well from 800 MHz to 1 GHz with a reflection coefficient of -26.110 dB at 920 MHz (p. 8); The measured peak gain of the proposed fractal antenna is 3.148 dBi (p. 9); The reflection coefficient is -26.110 dB and the VSWR is 1.104 at the required operating frequency (p. 11); The proposed antenna resonates well from 800 MHz to 1 GHz with 𝒇=920 MHz (p. 11); The measured peak antenna gain is 3.148 dBi (p. 11)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The long-range test confirmed a reliable link between the CubeSat and the ground sensor terminal (GST) (p. 10); The proposed fractal antenna offers better performance against a conventional UHF antenna (p. 11); The fractal antenna exhibits a VSWR of 1.104 at 920 MHz (p. 9)
gen.discussion: The proposed fractal antenna solves the challenge of designing non-deployable, low-profile, and compact antennas for the UHF band. The inclusion of a ground plane with a similar geometry as the radiating patch is a novel approach in CubeSat antennas (p. 11)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Simulation Environment | description: The simulation environment does not include the other modules of the actual CubeSat, which could affect the reliability of the measured results (p. 9); limitation_type: Design | description: The study focuses on a specific patch size and geometry, and future works should investigate other patch geometries (p. 11)

gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Exhibit a reflection coefficient of -26.110 dB and a VSWR of 1.104 at the required operating frequency (p. 11); Resonate well from 800 MHz to 1 GHz with 𝒇=920 MHz (p. 11); Fabricate the antenna and perform field tests to validate its performance (p. 2); Simulate and analyze the performance of the fractal antenna using HFSS (p. 2); Achieve a peak antenna gain of 3.148 dBi (p. 11)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Perform a link budget analysis to determine power requirements and set up modulation parameters for signal transmission and reception (p. 10); Investigate optimized results for other patch geometries (p. 11)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use a ground plane with a similar geometry as the radiating patch (p. 11); Consider the CubeSat frame in antenna design (p. 11); Consider the impact of other CubeSat modules on the antenna performance in future designs (p. 9)

gen.conclusions: The design of the CP, high-gain, single-feed, and single-layer S-band patch antenna for small-satellite applications has been successfully presented. The antenna exhibits the desired performance metrics and can be integrated with the HORYU-IV small-satellite communications. This project brought together engineers from different disciplines, while allowing students to absorb valuable knowledge about the development cycle of real-world engineering projects (p. 6)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Comparison of simulated and measured results for reflection coefficients, axial ratio, gain, and radiation patterns (p. 4)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Simulation software (Altair FEKO) (p. 6); Agilent N5227A network analyzer for measurements (p. 4); Anechoic chamber for testing (p. 6); HFSS 15 for electromagnetic full-wave simulation (p. 4); Satimo StarLab for radiation pattern measurements (p. 4)
gen.detailed_methodology.population_cont: HORYU-IV nanosatellite, a 30-cm3 satellite under development at the Kyushu Institute of Technology (p. 2)

gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design and testing of a specific antenna (p. 6)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The antenna achieved a 7.29 dBi gain at 2.285 GHz (p. 4); The antenna exhibits an effective bandwidth of 2.73% from 2.2450 to 2.3075 GHz for 10-dB return loss and 3-dB AR bandwidth at 13 MHz (p. 6); The 3-dB AR beamwidth is about 1560 at 2.285 GHz (p. 6); The antenna produced right-hand circular polarization (RHCP) waves in the Z > 0 half-space (p. 4); The impedance bandwidth was 2.73% (2.2450–2.3075 GHz) (p. 4); The measured gain of the antenna prototype is around 7.29 dBi (p. 6); The 3-dB axial ratio bandwidth was 0.74% (2.278–2.295 GHz) (p. 4)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The antenna had a broad field of view and high gain at low elevation angles (p. 4); Measured parameters show good agreement with the numerical modeling (p. 6); The radiation efficiency was over 96% at 2.285 GHz (p. 4)
gen.discussion: The design of the CP, high-gain, single-feed, and single-layer S-band patch antenna for small-satellite applications has been successfully presented. The antenna exhibits the desired performance metrics and can be integrated with the HORYU-IV small-satellite communications (p. 6)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Measurement | description: Minor soldering imperfections affected the S11 and S22 parameters (p. 5); limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study is specific to the HORYU-IV project and may not be directly applicable to other small-satellite applications (p. 6)

gen.objectives.main_objective: To develop a compact, high-gain, circularly polarized microstrip patch antenna for the HORYU-IV nanosatellite S-band communication (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: To achieve an effective bandwidth of 2.73% from 2.2450 to 2.3075 GHz for 10-dB return loss and 3-dB AR bandwidth at 13 MHz (p. 6); To measure the gain and 3-dB AR beamwidth of the antenna prototype (p. 6); Maintain less than 3-dB axial ratio for the entire field of view (p. 1); Achieve a sufficient beamwidth for LEO satellite application (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Further testing and optimization of the antenna design for broader applications (p. 6); Investigate the performance of the antenna in different satellite missions and environments (p. 5)

gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Traditional satellite communication systems suffer from high costs and large antenna sizes, making them unsuitable for small satellites. Microstrip antennas, while lightweight and low-profile, often have low gain and require circular polarization for orientation-related issues (p. 2)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a CP, high-gain, single-feed, and single-layer S-band patch antenna be designed for small-satellite applications? (p. 6); How can a compact, high-gain, circularly polarized microstrip patch antenna be designed for small satellite applications? (p. 2)

gen.conclusions: The proposed antenna design is effective and can be integrated with small satellites for reliable communication. The project brought together engineers from different disciplines and provided valuable knowledge to students about real-world engineering projects (p. 6)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Comparison of simulated and measured results for reflection coefficients, axial ratio, gain, and radiation patterns (p. 4)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Agilent N5227A network analyzer for measurements (p. 4); Satimo StarLab for radiation pattern measurement (p. 4); Numerical modeling using simulation software (p. 6); HFSS 15 for electromagnetic full-wave simulation (p. 4); Environmental and mechanical testing in the KYUTECH Laboratory of Spacecraft Environment Interaction Engineering (LaSEINE) (p. 6)
gen.detailed_methodology.population_cont: HORYU-IV nanosatellite, a 30-cm3 satellite under development at the Kyushu Institute of Technology (p. 2)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and simulation of a microstrip patch antenna with asymmetric V-shaped slits and a parasitic strip (pp. 2-3)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The antenna achieved a 7.29 dBi gain at 2.285 GHz (p. 4); The antenna exhibits an effective bandwidth of 2.73% from 2.2450 to 2.3075 GHz for 10-dB return loss and 3-dB AR bandwidth at 13 MHz (p. 6); The impedance and AR bandwidth are sufficient to cover the HORYU-IV S-band communication requirement (p. 4); The 3-dB AR beamwidth is about 1560 at 2.285 GHz (p. 6); The measured gain of the antenna prototype is around 7.29 dBi (p. 6); The 3-dB axial ratio bandwidth was 0.74% (2.278–2.295 GHz) (p. 4)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: Measured parameters show good agreement with the numerical modeling (p. 6); The antenna produces right-hand CP (RHCP) waves in the Z > 0 half-spaces, with a forward RHCP wave 27 dB larger than the backward RHCP wave and 17 dB larger than the backward LHCP (p. 4)
gen.discussion: The design of the CP, high-gain, single-feed, and single-layer S-band patch antenna for small-satellite applications has been successfully presented. The antenna's performance confirms its potential for integration with HORYU-IV small-satellite communications (p. 6)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Measurement | description: Minor soldering imperfections affected the S11 and S22 parameters (p. 5); limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study is specific to the HORYU-IV project and may not be directly applicable to other satellite designs (p. 6)

gen.conclusions: A semi-analytical design approach for dual-mode resonant microstrip antennas with electrically small patch size and tilted CP angle for satellite-assisted IoV has been systematically advanced. This is the first work to implement such antennas with frequency scannable tilted CP angle while maintaining low profile and simple configuration (p. 9)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Simulation and measurement of reflection coefficients, radiation patterns, and AR (p. 6)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Satimo’s Starlab near-field antenna measurement system (p. 6); Agilent’s N5230A vector network analyzer (p. 6); Numerical simulation software for antenna performance (p. 4); Not mentioned; MATLAB for eigen-root calculations (p. 3); HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 2)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Semi-analytical design approach (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The antenna exhibits a wideband radiation characteristic with a tilted CP angle (p. 4); Ant. 2 exhibits a wider tilted CP bandwidth of 26.6% and a larger tilted frequency scanning angle range (p. 8); The proposed antenna design achieves an electrically small radius of 0.157 wavelengths (p. 3); Not mentioned; Ant. 1 exhibits a wideband, dual-mode resonant characteristic with impedance bandwidth of 27.3% and tilted CP bandwidth of 21.4% (p. 6)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: Not mentioned; The antenna design can be implemented with a single-layer air substrate and a relative permittivity of ɛr = 1 (p. 4); Ant. 1 can exhibit tilted CP frequency scanning functionality in the elevation plane (p. 7); Ant. 2 has a maximum gain of 5.16 dBic at θ_t = 5° and an average radiation efficiency of 92.5% (p. 9)
gen.discussion: The advanced design approach has been supported by mode synthesis charts and a set of analytical formulas with generality, making it easy to design antennas at different frequency bands for satellite applications while maintaining radiation performance (p. 9)

gen.conclusions: The low-profile antenna array with high gain performance is a significant advancement for CubeSat applications, particularly in 5G. Future work will focus on optimizing antenna excitations and exploring aperture-coupled antennas to further increase gain (p. 11)

gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and simulation of a microstrip patch antenna array using CST Studio Suite® software, followed by fabrication and experimental validation (p. 2)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The array was successfully mounted on a CubeSat structure and tested (p. 11); The proposed design achieves high gain performance with a low profile (p. 11); The proposed 4 × 4 antenna array achieved a measured gain of 8.03 dBi and a reflection coefficient of −17.4 dB at 3.5 GHz (p. 1); The array operates within the 5G low-frequency band from 3.46 GHz to 3.54 GHz (p. 9)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The array's radiation pattern is unidirectional, concentrating radiation in the center of the array (p. 8); The design is suitable for 5G applications in CubeSats (p. 11)
gen.discussion: The design meets the requirements for 5G CubeSat applications by combining high gain with a low profile, making it suitable for integration into the limited space of a CubeSat (p. 1)

gen.conclusions: The reconfigurable antenna design using adhesive polyimide tapes is a viable solution for CubeSats, providing the ability to switch between patch and monopole modes with minimal actuation complexity (p. 1)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Comparison of simulated and measured performance metrics (p. 5)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Measurements in an anechoic chamber (p. 3); Simulations using HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 2); Simulations using HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 5); Measurements in an anechoic chamber (p. 5)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Experimental and simulation-based (pp. 2-4)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The antenna achieved 6.9% bandwidth with S11 < −10 dB in its patch state and 2.6% bandwidth with S11 < −10 dB in its monopole state (p. 5); The patch mode has a gain of 7.7 dBi and a bandwidth of 2.0% (p. 4); The measured patterns for both states agree with simulations (p. 5); The antenna can switch between patch and monopole modes with minimal actuation complexity (p. 1); The monopole mode has a gain of 1.2 dBi and a bandwidth of 4.1% (p. 4)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The monopole mode has a maximum radiation near θ = 90° and a null depth of approximately −10 dB at θ = 0° (p. 3); The antenna operates at 2.4 GHz (p. 5); The patch mode has a maximum radiation along θ = 0° and is ˆφ polarized along the φ = 0° plane (p. 3)
gen.discussion: The reconfigurable antenna design using adhesive polyimide tapes provides a low-cost, mechanically simple solution for CubeSats, enabling multiple wireless links with the same radio (p. 1)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Mechanical sensitivity | description: The patch configuration is highly sensitive to any air gap between the patch radiator and the substrate (p. 3); limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study is limited to a specific frequency band and may not be directly applicable to other bands (p. 5)

gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and simulation of a shared aperture antenna (pp. 2-3)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The Axial Ratio (<3 dB) bandwidth of the slot antenna in the S-band is 7 MHz (2013–2020 MHz, 0.35%), and it is 67 MHz (8433–8500 MHz, 0.8%) in the case of patch antenna in the X-band (p. 1); The S-band patch had a simulated maximum RHCP gain of 7.7 dBic at 2016 MHz (p. 5); The X-band patch achieved a simulated S11 < −10 dB bandwidth of 210 MHz (2.5%) and a measured bandwidth of 270 MHz (p. 8); Not mentioned; The X-band patch had a simulated maximum RHCP gain of 12.8 dBic at 8460 MHz (p. 6); The maximum gain in the S-band reached 7.7 dBic, and in the X-band, the peak gain was 12.8 dBic (p. 1); The S-band patch had an S11 = −10 dB bandwidth of 30 MHz (2013–2043 MHz, 1.5%), and the X-band antenna demonstrated a bandwidth of 210 MHz (8320–8530 MHz, 2.5%) (p. 1); The S-band patch achieved a simulated S11 < −10 dB bandwidth of 30 MHz (1.5%) and a measured bandwidth of 16 MHz (p. 6)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The antenna is advantageous in terms of high gain, maintains circular polarization over a wideband, and can replace two antennas needed in CubeSats for uplink/downlink, saving space (p. 1); Not mentioned; The fabricated prototype exhibited good isolation between ports of the S-band and X-band patches (below −20 dB in the S-band and −15 dB in the X-band) (p. 8)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna design effectively addresses the space limitations and performance requirements of CubeSats by combining S-band and X-band operations in a single, compact structure (pp. 1-2)

gen.detailed_results.main_findings: S-band patch has S11 < -10dB bandwidth from 2013MHz to 2043MHz (30MHz, 1.5%) (p. 2); S-band patch has Axial Ratio (AR) < 3dB bandwidth from 2013MHz to 2020MHz (7MHz, 0.35%) (p. 2); At 2016MHz, the minimum AR is 1.9dB and the maximum Right-Hand Circular Polarization (RHCP) Gain is 7.7dBic (p. 2); X-band FPRA has S11 < -10dB bandwidth from 8320MHz to 8530MHz (210MHz, 2.5%) (p. 2); X-band FPRA has 3dB Axial Ratio bandwidth from 8433MHz to 8500MHz (67MHz, 0.8%) (p. 2); At 8460MHz, the minimum AR is 0.9 dB and the maximum gain is 12.8dBic (p. 2)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The X-band antenna pattern is more directive due to the PRS placed approximately at 0.5λ ∘ (λ∘ being free-space wavelength at X band frequency) from the X-band patch (p. 2)
gen.discussion: The proposed SAA design reuses the antenna aperture, allowing both uplink and downlink communications using a single antenna system, making it very attractive for CubeSat applications due to its compactness (p. 2)

gen.conclusions: The proposed CP-SAA can be an excellent option to substitute three separate antennas in a CubeSat used for GPS, uplink, and downlink communication and thus help with power and mass requirements of the CubeSat. Based on mission requirements, an array of X-band antennas inside the slots of the GPS antenna can be implemented, which will further improve the performance of the antenna (p. 2)

gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The GPS antenna has a VSWR<2 bandwidth from 1569 MHz to 1595 MHz (26 MHz, 1.64%) and an AR<3 dB bandwidth of 6 MHz (0.38%, 1573 MHz to 1579 MHz) (p. 2); The X-band FPRA has a VSWR<2 bandwidth from 10.12 GHz to 13.43 GHz (3.31 GHz, 28.11%) and an AR<3 dB bandwidth from 10.78 GHz to 11.69 GHz (910 MHz, 8.1%) (p. 2); The X-band antenna has three distinct AR minima at 10.83 GHz, 11.09 GHz, and 11.53 GHz with peak RHCP gains of 9 dBic, 10.82 dBic, and 11.77 dBic, respectively (p. 2)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The X-band antenna has higher gain and wider bandwidth compared to other wideband RHCP antennas for CubeSats (p. 2); The antenna can cover both uplink and downlink frequencies used by a CubeSat (p. 2); The antenna has an 11.77 dBic RHCP gain from a single patch, which is greater than the gain achieved by a 2×2 microstrip patch antenna array (p. 2)
gen.discussion: The proposed CP-SAA can be an excellent option to substitute three separate antennas in a CubeSat used for GPS, uplink, and downlink communication, thus helping with power and mass requirements of the CubeSat (p. 2)

gen.conclusions: Designing a CubeSat antenna at the lower end of the UHF spectrum is a challenging task. There are too many constraints, and the designer cannot enhance one aspect of the antenna without seriously compromising another. The specifications lead inevitably to the implementation of an electrically small antenna. It would be highly desirable to be able to implement an electrically large antenna (2ka >), or even a resonant-size antenna (12 ka<<). Such a radiator would have significantly better performance, and it would aid the link budget with its higher gain. The need for higher gain becomes evident if we consider that the path loss for a CubeSat is about 140 dB. However, since the outer dimensions of CubeSats are fixed, this would be possible only if the system switched to higher frequencies (e.g. 0.9 or 2.4 GHz) (p. 5)

gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: Not mentioned; The total efficiency of the antenna varies between 29 – 33% throughout the service band (p. 4); The maximum gain of the antenna varies between 0.7 – 1.4 dB throughout the service band (p. 4)
gen.discussion: The antenna design achieves significant miniaturization while maintaining acceptable performance, making it suitable for CubeSat applications (p. 4)

gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Explore further miniaturization techniques to improve bandwidth and efficiency (p. 4); An interesting subject of future work is to study different length distributions (tapering) for the peripheral slits. The triangular tapering seemed like a natural choice, but there are other options, e.g. binomial, cosine-on-pedestal, etc. It would be interesting to see how the other distributions perform in terms of the size-bandwidth trade-off, because each distribution will affect the electrical length and the input impedance of the antenna differently (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the designed antenna for CubeSat applications where miniaturization and circular polarization are required (p. 4); Not mentioned

gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The proposed antenna achieved bidirectional opposite-sense circularly polarized radiation with good performance (p. 4); The 10-dB impedance bandwidth was 57 MHz from 2.123 to 2.180 GHz (p. 3); The minimum reflection coefficient was -37.03 dB at 2.163 GHz (p. 3); The minimum axial ratios were 0.49 dB for frontward (1z direction, θ = 0°) radiation and 0.32 dB for backward (2z direction, θ = 180°) radiation at 2.153 GHz (p. 3); The 3-dB AR bandwidths were about 21 MHz for frontward (1z direction, θ = 0°) radiation and 12 MHz for backward (2z direction, θ = 180°) radiation at the resonant frequency of 2.153 GHz (p. 3); The RHCP gain was -1.81 dBic at 2.153 GHz for the front direction, and the LHCP gain was -2.55 dBic at 2.153 GHz for the backward direction (p. 3)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The cross-polarization ratio was 30.89 dB toward the 1z direction (θ = 0°) and 29.85 dB toward the 2z direction (θ = 180°) at 2.153 GHz (p. 3)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna design successfully achieved bidirectional opposite-sense circularly polarized radiation, making it a suitable candidate for CubeSat communication systems (p. 4)
