gen.conclusions: The proposed CP isoflux beam antenna array is a feasible solution for CubeSat earth coverage applications, offering a low profile, light weight, and ease-of-integration. The design and method can be extended to other beam-shaping applications (p. 2)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Radiation pattern modelling, impedance matching characterization, and hybrid synthesis (p. 2)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Radiation pattern modelling method (p. 2); Hybrid synthesis program (p. 2); Overall reflection coefficient (p. 2); Measurement equipment (p. 9); HFSS for simulation (p. 6); R&S ZVA67 VNA for reflection coefficient measurement (p. 8); Simulation software (Ansys HFSS) (p. 9); Not mentioned; MVG Starlab antenna pattern measurement system for radiation performance measurement (p. 8)
gen.detailed_methodology.population_cont: CubeSat with a 400 km orbit and a circular earth coverage area of 250 km² (p. 6)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and simulation of a sequential rotation-fed annular aperture antenna array (p. 10)
gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design and fabrication of a prototype (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: Efficiency reaches 90% at the working frequency band 5 GHz ± 50 MHz (p. 6); The proposed array features a low profile (0.078 𝜆0), light weight, and ease-of-integration for CubeSat earth coverage applications (p. 1); The array can produce a good axisymmetric radiation pattern due to its axisymmetric structure (p. 2); The proposed antenna array achieved a peak gain of 3.48 dBic at 5 GHz (p. 9); The maximum realized gain of 4.7 dBic occurs at θ = ±35°, while the realized gain at θ = 0° is 2.2 dBic (p. 6); The antenna array has a low profile of 4.688 mm (p. 10); The spatial AR beamwidth was 110° (p. 10); Not mentioned; AR is less than 3 dB within θ = ±35° (p. 6)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The array can be extended to other beam-shaping applications (p. 2); The design method is suitable for high-band CubeSat applications (p. 10); Not mentioned; The simulated -10-dB bandwidth is from 4 to 5.6 GHz, while the measured one is from 4.2 to 5.9 GHz (p. 8); The overall operating bandwidth of the prototype ranges from 4.9 to 5.09 GHz (p. 8); The antenna array is light weight and easy to fabricate (p. 10)
gen.discussion: The proposed CP isoflux beam antenna array is suitable for CubeSat earth coverage applications due to its low profile, light weight, and ease-of-integration. The design and method can also be extended to other beam-shaping applications (p. 2)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Not mentioned | description: Not mentioned; limitation_type: Measurement | description: It is difficult to measure the performance of the feeding network due to the large quantity of ports and the 4 closely-placed output ports for the inner aperture element (p. 7); limitation_type: Application | description: The design method is more suitable for high-band CubeSat applications due to size constraints (p. 10)

gen.metadata.title: Low-Profile Circularly-Polarized Isoflux Beam Antenna Array Based on Annular Aperture Elements for CubeSat Earth Coverage Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and demonstrate a low-profile 5 GHz sequential rotation-fed antenna array with isoflux radiation pattern for CubeSat earth coverage applications (p. 10)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a low profile and light weight design (p. 10); Optimize the radiator and feeding network parameters to achieve the desired performance (p. 6); Deduce an overall reflection coefficient to characterize impedance matching (p. 2); Design and fabricate a prototype operating at C band (5 GHz) (p. 1); Develop a radiation pattern modelling method for the array (p. 2); Not mentioned; Meet the frequency, footprint size, profile, polarization, AR, gain, and efficiency requirements (p. 6); Ensure good electrical performance (p. 10); Compare performance with existing designs (p. 10)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Not mentioned; Investigate the impact of different substrate materials and thicknesses (p. 7); Explore the use of the antenna array in different CubeSat missions (p. 7); Explore the application of the design method to other frequency bands (p. 10)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; Use the proposed design for CubeSat earth coverage applications (p. 10); Further optimization of the feeding network to improve performance (p. 7)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Small satellites, particularly CubeSats, require antennas with stringent indicators such as low mass, low profile, small size, and mechanical robustness. Current antenna designs for earth coverage beams are often bulky and heavy, limiting their application in CubeSats (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a low-profile antenna array be designed for CubeSat applications? (p. 10); How can the antenna array meet the requirements for a 400 km-orbit CubeSat with a circular earth coverage area of 250 km²? (p. 6); What are the optimal parameters for achieving the required radiation pattern and performance metrics? (p. 6); How can a low-profile, light-weight, and easy-to-integrate antenna array be designed for CubeSat earth coverage applications? (p. 1); Not mentioned; What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna array compared to existing designs? (p. 10)

esp.domain_results.gain: 4.7 dBic at θ = ±35°, 2.2 dBic at θ = 0° (p. 6)

gen.conclusions: The 3-D printed FSP antenna array with an integrated feeding circuit can provide consistent fabrication quality and dual-band circularly polarised radiation, suitable for CubeSat applications (p. 3)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Measurement of S-parameters, gain, and radiation patterns using an anechoic chamber and simulation software (p. 4)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: CST simulation software (p. 2); 3-D metal printing technology (p. 4); Anechoic chamber for measurements (p. 3); Anechoic chamber for measurements (p. 4); 3-D metal printing technology (p. 2); HFSS FEM method and QNM package for simulation (p. 4)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Experimental and simulation-based (pp. 1-3)
gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design and fabrication of a 3-D printed FSP antenna array (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The 3-D printed FSP antenna array achieved consistent fabrication quality and dual-band operation (p. 2); The measured right-handed circular polarised realised gains were 2.32 dBic at 1.2 GHz and 1.84 dBic at 2.45 GHz (p. 3); The proposed antenna design outperforms other designs in terms of size, dual-band functionality, and efficiency (p. 4); The 2 by 2 array achieved a maximum realised gain of 2.32 dBic at 1.2 GHz and 1.84 dBic at 2.45 GHz (p. 5)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The 3-dB axial ratio beamwidth was 125° at 1.2 GHz and 74° at 2.45 GHz (p. 3); The total antenna efficiency remains high despite miniaturisation (p. 5)
gen.discussion: The 3-D printed FSP antenna array offers good radiation performance, particularly in terms of realised CP gains and AR beamwidth, which can be required for CubeSat applications (p. 3)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Measurement Setup | description: Minor beam squint and interference from the antenna positioner and connected cable during measurements (p. 3); limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study is limited to a specific design and may not be directly applicable to all CubeSat configurations (p. 5)

gen.conclusions: A compact design of a Yagi antenna that was printed on FR4 substrate with an integrated balun is presented in this paper. The proposed antenna provides an adaptive frequency operation in the L-band (p. 8)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Simulation and measurement results compared to validate the design (p. 9)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Measurement equipment in an anechoic chamber (p. 9); Simulation software (p. 4); Not mentioned; Simulation software (p. 2); Measurement in an anechoic chamber (p. 2); Simulation software (p. 9); Measurement of fabricated antenna (p. 9)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and simulation of a printed Yagi antenna with a tapered balun integrated on an FR4 substrate (p. 4)
gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design and fabrication of a patch antenna (p. 9)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The antenna design achieves a total measured gain of 8.16 dBi, 5.78 dBi, and 6.12 dBi at 3 GHz, 1.3 GHz, and 2.4 GHz respectively (p. 9); The measured gain is 8.167 dBi at 2.4 GHz, 5.278 dBi at 1.3 GHz, and 6.120 dBi at 3 GHz (p. 1); Not mentioned; The antenna achieves −10 dB bandwidths of 250 MHz at 3 GHz, 100 MHz at 1.3 GHz, and 190 MHz at 2.4 GHz (p. 9); The proposed antenna achieves adaptive frequency operation in the L-band (1.3–1.4 GHz) and S-band (2.38–2.54 GHz and 2.82–3.08 GHz) (p. 9); The antenna design achieves a total measured gain of 8.16 dBi at 3 GHz, 5.78 dBi at 1.3 GHz, and 6.12 dBi at 2.4 GHz (p. 9); The antenna operates at three different frequencies: 1.3 GHz (L-band), 2.4 GHz (S-band), and 3 GHz (S-band) (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The measurements of the fabricated antenna are in good agreement with the simulation (p. 9); Not mentioned; The measurements of the fabricated antenna are in good agreement with the simulation results (p. 9); The antenna has similar radiation patterns at different frequencies (p. 1)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna design provides a low-cost, compact, and high-performance solution for CubeSat missions, with the capability for multi-frequency operation and high gains at different angles and frequency bands (p. 9)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The performance of the antenna is specific to the CubeSat platform and may vary in other applications (p. 1); limitation_type: Deployment mechanism | description: The deployment mechanism for multi-angle operations may add complexity and weight to the CubeSat (p. 4); limitation_type: Not mentioned | description: Not mentioned; limitation_type: Measurement conditions | description: The measurements were conducted in a specific anechoic chamber, which may not fully represent all operational environments (p. 9)

gen.metadata.title: A New Patch Antenna for CubeSat: Dual feed, L/S dual-band stacked, and circularly polarized
gen.objectives.main_objective: To propose a printed Yagi antenna with an integrated balun for CubeSat communications that can operate at multiple frequencies with high gain and a simple design (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Maintain high gains at different angles and frequency bands (p. 4); Not mentioned; Achieve −10 dB bandwidths of 250 MHz at 3 GHz, 100 MHz at 1.3 GHz, and 190 MHz at 2.4 GHz (p. 9); Achieve adaptive frequency operation by adjusting the angle between the antenna and satellite (p. 4); Design a mechanically adjustable antenna to achieve three functional states at different operating frequencies (p. 1); Evaluate the performance metrics such as gain, bandwidth, and radiation patterns (p. 1); Achieve a total measured gain of 8.16 dBi, 5.78 dBi, and 6.12 dBi at 3 GHz, 1.3 GHz, and 2.4 GHz respectively (p. 9)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Explore the use of other low-cost materials for antenna substrates (p. 4); Investigation of the antenna's performance in space environments (p. 9); Not mentioned; Further testing and optimization of the antenna design for different CubeSat configurations (p. 1); Investigate more elaborate deployment mechanisms for multi-angle operations (p. 4)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; CubeSat designers can choose from three popular frequencies through a simple angle configuration (p. 1); Integrate the proposed antenna design in CubeSat missions to enhance communication capabilities (p. 9); Further testing in different environmental conditions (p. 9)

esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Compared with other printed Yagi antenna designs, our proposed antenna provides the highest gain at angle A = 10°, that is 8.167 dBi in measurement, however, its bandwidth is narrower. Reference [17] shows higher value of gain than other designs, but the size of this antenna is 43 mm longer than our proposed structure (p. 7)
esp.domain_results.gain: 8.167 dBi at 2.4 GHz, 5.278 dBi at 1.3 GHz, 6.120 dBi at 3 GHz (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Directional behavior on both planes when A = 90° and 50°. When A = 10°, the measured radiation pattern is closer to unidirectional on θ = 90° and obvious directional on φ = 90° (p. 6)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Dual feed, L/S dual-band stacked, circularly polarized patch antenna (p. 9)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: FR4 substrate, with a dielectric constant of 4.4 and a thickness of 0.6 mm (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: SubMiniature version A (SMA) coaxial connector was used to feed the antenna through the central feeding line and grounded on the tapered balun (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.frequency_b: L-band (1.3–1.4 GHz) and S-band (2.38–2.54 GHz and 2.82–3.08 GHz) (p. 9)

gen.conclusions: The proposed Yagi antenna with an integrated balun on FR4 substrate is a suitable candidate for CubeSat missions due to its compact volume, low profile, and high performance at multiple frequency bands (p. 9)

gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Measurement equipment in an anechoic chamber (p. 9); Simulation software (p. 4); Simulation software (p. 1); Measurement in an anechoic chamber (p. 1); Not mentioned; Simulation software (p. 9); Measurement of fabricated antenna (p. 9)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and simulation of a printed Yagi antenna with a tapered balun integrated on an FR4 substrate (p. 4)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The measured gain is 8.167 dBi at 2.4 GHz, 5.278 dBi at 1.3 GHz, and 6.120 dBi at 3 GHz (p. 1); The proposed antenna achieves adaptive frequency operation in the L-band (1.3–1.4 GHz) and S-band (2.38–2.54 GHz and 2.82–3.08 GHz) by adjusting the angle between the antenna and the satellite (p. 9); Not mentioned; The antenna also achieves −10 dB bandwidths of 250 MHz at 3 GHz, 100 MHz at 1.3 GHz, and 190 MHz at 2.4 GHz (p. 9); The antenna achieves −10 dB bandwidths of 250 MHz at 3 GHz, 100 MHz at 1.3 GHz, and 190 MHz at 2.4 GHz (p. 9); The antenna design achieves a total measured gain of 8.16 dBi at 3 GHz, 5.78 dBi at 1.3 GHz, and 6.12 dBi at 2.4 GHz (p. 9); The antenna operates at three different frequencies: 1.3 GHz (L-band), 2.4 GHz (S-band), and 3 GHz (S-band) (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The measurements of the fabricated antenna are in good agreement with the simulation (p. 9); Not mentioned; The measurements of the fabricated antenna are in good agreement with the simulation results, proving the reconfiguration technique of the design (p. 9); The antenna has similar radiation patterns at all three operating frequencies (p. 1)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna design provides a low-cost, compact, and high-performance solution for CubeSat missions, with the capability for multi-frequency operation and high gain at different frequency bands (p. 9)

esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Compared with other printed Yagi antenna designs, e.g., those listed in Table 1, our proposed antenna provides the highest gain at angle A = 10°, that is 8.167 dBi in measurement, however, its bandwidth is narrower. Reference [17] shows higher value of gain than other designs, but the size of this antenna is 43 mm longer than our proposed structure. Thus, besides the adaptive frequency operation, the proposed antenna with tapered balun provides good gain performance in terms of higher gain, and a low reflection coefficient based on the feasible size for CubeSat applications (p. 7)

gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design, fabrication, and measurement of a single-layer metasurface-integrated patch antenna (p. 2)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The metasurface-integrated patch antenna has a wide frequency band from 7.55 to 9.93 GHz (–10 dB BW 2.38 GHz) (p. 10); It has a unidirectional radiation pattern and is lightweight with a realized gain of about 7.0 dBi at 8.4 GHz (p. 10); The metasurface antenna achieved a peak gain of 7.0 dBi, a 16% improvement over the patch antenna alone (p. 5); The antenna has a unidirectional radiation pattern and a realized gain of around 7.0 dBi at 8.4 GHz (p. 1); The metasurface-integrated patch antenna achieved an ultra-wide bandwidth of 7.55 to 9.93 GHz (–10 dB BW of 2.38 GHz) (p. 1); The antenna has an ultra-wide bandwidth of 2.38 GHz (7.55 to 9.93 GHz) and a low reflection coefficient of -44.27 dB at 8.59 GHz (p. 6)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The metasurface improved the impedance bandwidth and reflection coefficient around 8.4 GHz without increasing the physical sizes or antenna volume (p. 4); The antenna has a unidirectional radiation pattern with a very wide beamwidth angle, suitable for 0.5U and 1U CubeSats (p. 6); The antenna meets the geometric, mechanical, and electrical criteria for 0.5U and 1U CubeSat missions in the X-band (p. 10)
gen.discussion: The results demonstrate that the new single-layer wideband metasurface antenna satisfies the needs of 0.5U and 1U CubeSat missions in the X-band, with improved performance and reduced data reception time (p. 10)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study focuses on 0.5U and 1U CubeSats, and the results may not be directly applicable to larger CubeSat configurations (p. 1); limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study is specific to 0.5U and 1U CubeSats and may not be directly applicable to larger CubeSat configurations (p. 7); limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study is specific to 0.5U and 1U CubeSat missions and may not be directly applicable to larger CubeSat configurations (p. 10)

gen.objectives.main_objective: To design, fabricate, and evaluate a single-layer metasurface antenna for X-band CubeSats that meets all geometrical, mechanical, and electrical requirements (p. 5)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a wide impedance bandwidth and unidirectional radiation pattern in the X-band (p. 10); Optimize impedance matching and electrical energy transfer to the radiating elements (p. 5); Design and optimize a tiny patch antenna that can cover 40% of a 0.5U CubeSat's smallest face and 20% of a 1U CubeSat's face (p. 2); Achieve high gain and wide bandwidth while maintaining a small size and low power consumption (p. 5); Ensure the antenna is lightweight and has adequate realized gain (p. 10); Employ metasurface to enhance antenna performance at X-band and improve earth station-CubeSat transmission quality (p. 2); Fabricate the metasurface-integrated patch antenna and measure its characteristics to validate its performance for 0.5U and 1U CubeSat missions (p. 2); Ensure the antenna is suitable for 0.5U and 1U CubeSat configurations (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the metasurface-integrated patch antenna in different orbital conditions and for larger CubeSat configurations (p. 1); Investigate the performance of the antenna in different CubeSat configurations and orbits (p. 7); Explore the integration of the antenna with other CubeSat subsystems (p. 7); Investigate new unit cell configurations for further performance improvements (p. 10); Explore the integration of an AMC layer and a multilayer Fabry-Perot antenna to increase gain to more than 20 dBi (p. 10)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the metasurface-integrated patch antenna design for 0.5U and 1U CubeSat missions to enhance data reception time and minimize air resistance (p. 1); Integrate the metasurface-integrated patch antenna in 0.5U and 1U CubeSat designs (p. 10); Use the antenna for high-speed data transmission and efficient energy use (p. 10); Ensure proper impedance matching and electrical energy transfer to the radiating elements (p. 5); Use the single-layer metasurface antenna for high-performance CubeSat communications (p. 7)

(p. 2); How can the designed metasurface-integrated patch antenna be fabricated and its characteristics measured to determine its effectiveness for 0.5U and 1U CubeSat missions? (p. 2); How can a single-layer metasurface antenna improve the performance of CubeSats in terms of gain, bandwidth, and impedance matching? (p. 5); What new unit cell shape can be optimized for the metasurface to enhance the overall efficiency of the CubeSat? (p. 10); How can the antenna be made smaller while maintaining good operational characteristics? (p. 10); How can the metasurface improve antenna performance at X-band while enhancing earth station-CubeSat transmission quality? (p. 2)

gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The cross-patch antenna with metasurface achieved a peak gain of 10.0 dBi at 8.4 GHz (p. 10); The antenna demonstrated a 3 dBi gain bandwidth greater than 1.0 GHz (p. 10); The fabricated cross-patch antenna with metasurface achieved a gain of 10.0 dBi and a 3 dBi gain bandwidth of 1.0 GHz at 8.4 GHz (p. 3); The antenna exhibited a unidirectional radiation pattern and substantial return losses (p. 10); The metasurface antenna achieved a peak gain of 10.0 dBi at 8.4 GHz, with a 3 dBi gain bandwidth of 1.0 GHz (p. 7); The reflection coefficient (|S11|) was measured at –31.3 dB at 8.4 GHz, indicating excellent impedance matching (p. 6); The antenna occupies only 6.84% of a 1U CubeSat's top face (10 × 10 cm²) (p. 3)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The metasurface antenna provided two VSWR bandwidths: 8.36 to 8.58 GHz and 8.75 to 9.49 GHz (p. 7); The antenna design is suitable for 1U and larger CubeSat configurations (p. 10); The antenna's radiation pattern was unidirectional with a wide beamwidth angle, suitable for CubeSat communication (p. 7); The antenna is lightweight and exhibits a unidirectional radiation pattern (p. 1); The antenna does not require deployment mechanisms after launch (p. 10)
gen.discussion: The metasurface antenna design significantly improves the performance of CubeSat communication systems, offering high gain, wide bandwidth, and low power consumption, making it suitable for various CubeSat configurations (pp. 7-8)

gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The proposed pixel patch design reduces the size by about 75% compared to conventional patches (p. 1); The full design area reduction is about 90% (p. 1); The proposed pixel patch element has a return loss of -23 dB and a VSWR of 1.16 at 5.32 GHz (p. 5); The proposed pixel patch design area reduction is approximately 75%, and the full design area reduction is approximately 90% (p. 14); The proposed pixel antenna array has a gain of up to 32.7 dB (p. 13)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The proposed pixel antenna array is smaller than traditional microstrip arrays with high gain and a relatively wide beam (p. 14); The proposed pixel patch element has a smaller size and lower order mode than traditional designs (p. 6)
gen.discussion: The proposed pixel antenna array is effective for small space devices and miniaturized systems due to its miniaturization and high gain. The design can be used in communications, wireless networks, CubeSat, IoT, ADAS, and V2X applications (p. 14)

gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The antenna has an apple-shaped pattern at 2.45 GHz and more directional characteristics at 2.04 GHz (p. 4); Realized gain up to 4 dBi and 2.15 dBi at two resonant frequencies of the antennas with different substrate heights (p. 1); Realized gain values from -1 dBi to 4 dBi at the first resonant frequency, and from -0.85 dBi to 2.15 dBi at the second resonant frequency (p. 8); The proposed antenna ensures efficient operation of the entire Earth-observation CubeSat system (p. 8)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The proposed antenna outperforms other designs in terms of compactness and gain (p. 8); At substrate height h = 2.5 mm, the -10 dB impedance bandwidth at resonant frequencies is 130 MHz (2350–2480 MHz) and 40 MHz (2010–2050 MHz) (p. 5); With an increase in substrate height, the resonant frequencies are shifted towards a decrease (p. 5); The antenna is compact, low-cost, and simple to execute (p. 8)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna design addresses the need for small-sized, high-gain antennas for S-band CubeSat nanosatellites. The integration of the optical imaging system and the antenna on the same surface optimizes the use of the CubeSat's surface area and increases energy security (p. 2)

gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The limited size and communication resources of CubeSat nanosatellites require advanced solutions in this area. gen.conclusions: The ADS-B antenna using superstrate and additional substrate layer for CubeSat is successfully designed, simulated, and measured. The antenna form factor meets the CubeSat standard, and the gain improvements were achieved with a result of 4.505 dBi. The return loss and bandwidth of the antenna are -18.940 dB and 23 MHz, respectively. The antenna has a circular polarization with an axial ratio less than 3 dB (p. 7)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Simulation results and measurement data compared (p. 6)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Simulation software (Altair FEKO) (p. 2); Measurement equipment in an anechoic chamber (p. 6); Measurement equipment in an anechoic chamber (p. 7); Simulation software (p. 7)

gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design and optimization of a microstrip antenna (p. 2)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The final design with a superstrate layer achieved a gain of 4.946 dBi in simulation and 4.505 dBi in measurement (p. 5); The antenna gain was improved to 4.505 dBi (p. 7); The bandwidth was 23 MHz (p. 7); The antenna has a circular polarization with an axial ratio less than 3 dB (p. 7); The return loss was -18.940 dB (p. 7); The initial design had a gain of -4.980 dBi, which was poor (p. 3)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The fabricated antenna had a bandwidth of 23 MHz (p. 6); The fabricated antenna had a circular polarization with an axial ratio under 3 dB (p. 6); The antenna form factor meets the CubeSat standard (p. 7); The fabricated antenna had a VSWR of 1.256 and a return loss of -18.940 dB (p. 6)
gen.discussion: The combination of managing the antenna patch dimension, adding truncated structure, increasing the substrate layer, and integrating the antenna with a superstrate layer successfully increases the antenna performance while maintaining its compact dimension (p. 7)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Measurement accuracy | description: The fabricated antenna's performance was slightly lower than the simulation results, possibly due to substrate characteristics (p. 6); limitation_type: Not mentioned | description: Not mentioned

gen.conclusions: A transparent meshed conductor and meshed substrate circularly polarized GPS microstrip antenna was successfully designed, simulated, fabricated, and tested, meeting the required specifications for Cubesat applications (p. 7)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Measurement of S11 parameter, antenna gain, bandwidth, and transparency (p. 8)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: S11 parameter measurement (p. 8); ROHDE&SCHARZ ZVB 20 Vector Network Analyzer (VNA) (p. 6); CST simulation software (p. 1); Bandwidth measurement (p. 8); Transparency measurement (p. 8); Antenna gain measurement (p. 8)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design, simulation, and fabrication of a transparent meshed conductor and meshed substrate microstrip antenna (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: Bandwidth of 60 MHz (3.82% of the operating frequency) (p. 8); S11 parameter of -45.38 dB at 1.575 GHz (p. 8); Antenna gain of 6.687 dBi (p. 8); The axial ratio is approximately 3 dB with an axial ratio bandwidth of 55 MHz (p. 5); The antenna gain is 6.687 dBi (p. 5); The percentage of transparency reaches approximately 71.5% (p. 5); The antenna efficiency is 97.49% (p. 5); The optimized antenna resonates at 1.575 GHz with a return loss of -45.83 dB (p. 5); The bandwidth is 60 MHz (3.82% of operating frequency) (p. 5); Transparency of about 71.5% (p. 8)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The 3-D radiation pattern shows the direction of maximum gain above the patch in the z-direction (p. 5); Fabricated antenna achieved S11 parameter of -15 dB at 1.48 GHz with a 5.7% error due to manufacturing tolerance and etching precision (p. 8)
gen.discussion: The design meets the required specifications for a transparent GPS L1 band microstrip antenna for Cubesat applications, with high transparency and efficiency (p. 5)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Fabrication | description: The measured S11 parameter showed a resonance frequency of 1.48 GHz with a 5.7% error due to manufacturing tolerances and etching precision (p. 6); limitation_type: Manufacturing | description: Percentage of error reaching 5.7% due to manufacturing tolerance and etching precision (p. 8)

gen.objectives.main_objective: To design, simulate, and fabricate a transparent meshed conductor and meshed substrate circularly polarized GPS L1 band microstrip antenna for Cubesat applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Meet desired specifications for S11 parameter, antenna gain, bandwidth, and transparency (p. 8); Achieve circular polarization with RHCP (p. 8); Achieve a resonance frequency of 1.575 GHz (p. 3); Achieve a percentage of transparency of at least 60% (p. 3); Achieve an antenna efficiency of at least 85% (p. 3); Achieve an antenna gain of at least 5 dBi (p. 3); Achieve a bandwidth of at least 2.9% of the resonance frequency (p. 3)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the impact of different substrate materials and meshing techniques on antenna performance (p. 7); Investigation of other transparent substrate materials (p. 8)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the designed antenna in Cubesat applications for improved performance and transparency (p. 7); Further optimization of manufacturing processes to reduce error (p. 8)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Microstrip antennas are opaque, preventing solar energy from reaching the Cubesat’s solar cells, thus a transparent microstrip antenna design is required (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a transparent microstrip antenna be designed for GPS L1 band applications in Cubesats? (p. 1); How can a transparent microstrip GPS antenna be designed to meet the desired specifications? (p. 8)

gen.conclusions: An ultra-wide band UWB antenna array design using Archimedean spiral shapes on FR-4 substrate with stacked RT 5880 substrate is presented, achieving higher gain and wider beam width, enhancing visibility between the satellite and the ground station (p. 2)

gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The monopole antenna (MASMA) operates from 6.8 to 24 GHz without stacked substrate and from 6 to 61 GHz with stacked substrate, with an 8 dB gain increase (p. 2); The dipole antenna (DASMA) operates from 7.5 to 24 GHz without stacked substrate and from 7.5 to 15 GHz with stacked substrate, with a 10 dB gain increase (p. 2); The 2x2 array of DASMA operates from 7.5 to 25 GHz without stacked substrate and from 5.8 to 16 GHz with stacked substrate, with a 12 dB gain increase (p. 2)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The stacked substrate technique improves the gain and bandwidth of all antenna designs (p. 2)
gen.discussion: The use of stacked substrate techniques significantly enhances the gain and bandwidth of Archimedean spiral microstrip antennas, making them suitable for ultra-wide band satellite communications (p. 2)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Simulation | description: The study is based on simulation results and may require experimental validation (p. 2)

gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Design a monopole Archimedean spiral microstrip antenna (MASMA) with and without stacked substrate (p. 1); Design a dipole Archimedean spiral microstrip antenna (DASMA) with and without stacked substrate (p. 1); Design a 2x2 array of DASMA with and without stacked substrate (p. 1)

gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use stacked substrate techniques to enhance the performance of spiral microstrip antennas in satellite communications (p. 2)

gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The proposed antenna operates over three bands: 3.75–5.25 GHz, 6.4–15.4 GHz, and 22.5–30 GHz (p. 6); Achieved high gain of 12.5 dBi (p. 20); Achieved 85% radiation efficiency (p. 20); Achieved a gain of 12.5 dBi and a radiation efficiency of 85% (p. 1); Achieves high gain (12.5 dBi) and radiation efficiency (85%) (p. 6); Offers beamsteering abilities without additional electrical or mechanical components (p. 6); Not mentioned; Operates in three bands (3.75–5.25 GHz, 6.4–15.4 GHz, and 22.5–30 GHz) (p. 1); Supports frequency- or phase-dependent beamsteering without mechanical parts (p. 1); Operates across three frequency bands: 3.75–5.25 GHz, 6.4–15.4 GHz, and 22.5–30 GHz (p. 20); Supports circular polarization, which can degrade signal interference between CubeSats (p. 6)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The antenna’s multilayered, stacked construction boosts gain and radiation efficiency (p. 7); The use of a cavity layer and air gap enhances gain and efficiency (p. 11); Stable circular polarization (p. 20); High gain and efficiency ensure reliable long-distance communication with low power consumption (p. 1); Compact size (40 × 30 mm²) meets CubeSat constraints (p. 1); Not mentioned; Wideband response (p. 20); Circular polarization (CP) maintains signal integrity despite orientation changes (p. 1); MIMO capability supports high data rates for applications such as Earth observations or inter-satellite links (p. 1); Beamsteering feature allows for dynamic tracking of ground stations or satellites, enhancing mission flexibility and reducing interference (p. 1); Nested slots reduce unwanted backside and end-fire radiation, resulting in a broadside radiation pattern (p. 7)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna meets the stringent SWaP requirements of CubeSats while offering enhanced performance and reliability. The MIMO capability supports high data rates, and the beamsteering ability improves CubeSat to ground station communication. The antenna’s low profile, high gain, and efficiency make it a reliable candidate for harsh environments like space (p. 6)

gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Operate in three bands (3.75–5.25 GHz, 6.4–15.4 GHz, and 22.5–30 GHz) (p. 1); Support frequency- or phase-dependent beamsteering without mechanical parts (p. 1); Achieve a gain of 12.5 dBi and a radiation efficiency of 85% (p. 1); Achieve high gain, radiation efficiency, and circular polarization (p. 6); Evaluate performance metrics such as gain, bandwidth, and return loss (p. 20); Not mentioned; Support high data rates and beamsteering abilities without electrical or mechanical sophistication (p. 6); Ensure reliable long-distance communication with low power consumption (p. 1); Ensure stable circular polarization (p. 20); Design a compact, dual-port MIMO antenna using a modified phased MTS with coffee bean-shaped arrays (p. 6); Achieve high gain and efficiency (p. 20)

gen.metadata.title: Microstrip Antenna with Slotted Rectangular Truncated Corner Patch for ADS-B Receiver on Cubesat
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and evaluate a microstrip antenna with a slotted rectangular truncated corner patch for ADS-B signal reception on a CubeSat (p. 2)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a gain of 4.22 dBi (p. 264); Evaluate the performance of the designed antenna through simulation and measurement (p. 2); Achieve a frequency range of 1084.6 - 1099.5 MHz (p. 264); Design an antenna that meets the required specifications for ADS-B signal reception (p. 2); Improve the axial ratio to 2.89 dB (p. 264)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the antenna in different orbital conditions (p. 6); Further optimization of the antenna design (p. 264)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the designed antenna into CubeSat missions for ADS-B signal reception (p. 6); Use the designed antenna for ADS-B receivers in Cubesats (p. 264)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Ground-based ADS-B signal receivers have limited coverage areas, especially in areas difficult to reach by terrestrial communication. Satellite-based ADS-B signal reception technology is needed to expand the signal reception coverage area (p. 2)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can the gain and axial ratio of the microstrip antenna be improved? (p. 264); How can a microstrip antenna with a slotted rectangular truncated corner patch improve the performance of ADS-B signal reception on a CubeSat? (p. 2); What is the impact of the truncated corner method on the antenna's performance? (p. 264)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 264)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Improvement in gain by 3.2 dB compared to previous research (p. 264)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Microstrip antenna with slotted rectangular truncated corner patch (p. 2)

gen.conclusions: The round-shape patch antenna is a potential candidate for use on a nanosatellite, with good matching properties and almost circular polarization in the desired frequency range (p. 7)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Comparison of simulated and measured results for S11, gain, and axial ratio (p. 5)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Electromagnetic field simulation software (CST Studio, Ansoft HFSS) (p. 4); Anechoic chamber for measurement (p. 5)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Theoretical study using high-frequency electromagnetic field simulation software, followed by manufacturing and validation measurements (p. 1)
gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Experimental design with simulation and measurement validation (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The antenna achieved a maximum realized gain of 9.35 dB at 2.5 GHz (p. 4); The measured S11 parameter remained below -6 dB in the frequency range from 2.2 to 2.6 GHz (p. 5); The minimum measured axial ratio was 1.5 dB at 2.35 GHz (p. 6)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The axial ratio values varied from 3 to 5.8 dB in the desired frequency range (p. 6)
gen.discussion: The results indicate that the designed antenna is a good candidate for installation on a nanosatellite, meeting the required performance and size constraints (p. 1)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Manufacturing | description: Technological mistakes during manufacturing, such as errors in the slots dimensions, can affect the S11 parameter (p. 5)
gen.metadata.keywords: Patch antenna; Circular polarized; Nanosatellite; S-band
gen.metadata.authors: Vasilii Semkin
gen.metadata.title: Design and Analysis of Circular-Polarized Patch Antenna at S-band for a Nanosatellite
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a circularly polarized patch antenna suitable for installation on a nanosatellite, with specific requirements for size, frequency band, and performance (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve matching properties with S11 below -6 dB (p. 3); Ensure circular polarization in the S-band (2.40–2.45 GHz) (p. 1); Fit the antenna within a 10 × 10 cm² ground platform (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Not mentioned
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Further improvements in axial ratio in the operating frequency range (p. 7)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a compact, lightweight, and efficient circularly polarized patch antenna for nanosatellites operating in the S-band (2–4 GHz) (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a circularly polarized patch antenna be designed to fit the dimensions and performance requirements of a nanosatellite? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: CST Studio and Ansoft HFSS (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Not mentioned
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_dim: Diameter of the circular patch element: 57 mm (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Circularly polarized patch antenna (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Feed point moved 11 mm toward the edge of the antenna (p. 3)

gen.conclusions: The optimized stacked patch antenna design is a lightweight, small-sized, and high-gain communication system suitable for CubeSat applications in the Ka-band. The multiphysics analysis confirms its feasibility and reliability in a LEO environment (p. 12)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm, finite difference time domain (FDTD) simulations, and heat transfer analysis (pp. 4-7)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Finite element analysis (FEA) for thermal and mechanical analysis (p. 2); Comsol Multiphysics for thermal and mechanical analysis (p. 7); CST Microwave Studio for electromagnetic simulations (p. 5); Not mentioned; Simulation software: Altair FEKO (p. 2); PSO algorithm for optimization (p. 9); Comsol for thermal and mechanical analysis (p. 11); Particle swarm optimization algorithm for bandwidth and matching (p. 2)
gen.detailed_methodology.population_cont: CubeSat applications in Low Earth Orbit (LEO) (p. 7)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Multiphysics analysis and particle swarm optimization (pp. 1-2)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: Achieved a bandwidth of 5.53 GHz at 33.185 GHz (p. 1); The optimized antenna design achieved a 10 dB bandwidth of 1 GHz and a return loss better than 10 dB (p. 6); Operational stability from -100 °C to 100 °C with almost constant gain (p. 1); Gain around 8 dB (p. 1); The antenna maintains its pointing direction over the Ka-bands (p. 10); Not mentioned; The thermal analysis showed that the antenna can withstand the thermal conditions of a LEO mission without significant thermal stresses (p. 7); The optimized antenna achieved a bandwidth of 16.6% (p. 10); An 8x8 array of the optimized antenna can achieve a gain of 26 dBi (p. 10)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: Mechanical deformation and stress analysis show negligible impact on antenna performance (p. 1); Not mentioned; The thermal and mechanical stresses are within acceptable limits for the materials used (p. 11); The mechanical analysis indicated that the antenna design is robust against thermal expansion and contraction (p. 7); The antenna's performance is stable over temperature variations (p. 11); Thermal loads can affect antenna matching, but the optimized design mitigates this effect (p. 1)
gen.discussion: The optimized antenna design meets the stringent communication requirements for CubeSat applications in the Ka-band, with a wide bandwidth and stable performance over temperature variations. The thermal and mechanical analysis confirms the feasibility of the design for LEO missions (pp. 11-12)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study is specific to a 1U CubeSat and may not be directly applicable to other CubeSat sizes or missions (p. 1); limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study is specific to a sun-synchronous circular orbit at 300 km altitude, and the results may not be directly applicable to other orbits or missions (p. 8); limitation_type: Material properties | description: The use of commercial prepreg and epoxy resins for the antenna assembly may present a risk of failure due to large temperature gradients in extremely cold orbital phases (p. 12); limitation_type: Not mentioned | description: Not mentioned
gen.metadata.keywords: particle swarm optimization; multiphysics; thermal stresses; multiphysics analysis; stacked antenna; Not mentioned; Ka-band; CubeSat; PSO algorithm; stacked patch antenna; optimization; thermal analysis; mechanical analysis
gen.metadata.authors: Nicola Curreli; Simone, F.; Lodi, M. B.; Giuseppe Mazzarella; Fanti, A.; Garcia, J.; Pavone, S. C.; Mazzarella, G.; Not mentioned; Alessandro Fanti; Simone, A.; Smith, A.B.; Simone, M.; Santi Concetto Pavone; Lopez, M.C.; Curreli, N.
gen.metadata.title: Optimized Design and Multiphysics Analysis of a Ka-Band Stacked Antenna for CubeSat Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and optimize a Ka-band stacked patch antenna for CubeSat applications, and to analyze its thermal and mechanical performance (p. 4)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Perform a multiphysics thermal and mechanical analysis to ensure operational stability (p. 1); Optimize the antenna geometry using a PSO algorithm (p. 8); Achieve a wideband operation and high gain (p. 1); Optimize the antenna design using Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) to achieve maximum bandwidth and return loss (p. 4); Conduct thermal and mechanical analysis to ensure the antenna can withstand the environmental conditions of a LEO mission (p. 7); Perform thermal and mechanical analysis of the antenna in a LEO environment (p. 8); Not mentioned; Evaluate the antenna performance in terms of bandwidth, gain, and radiation pattern (p. 8)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Explore the use of other materials and configurations for further optimization (p. 1); Investigate the performance of the antenna in different orbital environments (p. 1); Investigate the use of other epoxy resins capable of reaching high tensile, shear, and flexural stresses (p. 12); Not mentioned; Explore the optimization of other antenna types for CubeSat applications (p. 8); Investigate the impact of different orbits and mission profiles on antenna performance (p. 8)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the optimized design for future CubeSat missions (p. 1); Use mechanically performing resins or adaptive temperature control strategies to manage thermal and mechanical stresses (p. 12); Conduct further thermal and mechanical testing to validate the simulation results (p. 8); Not mentioned; Implement the optimized antenna design in CubeSat missions (p. 8); Perform similar multiphysics analyses for other CubeSat components (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need to optimize the design of a Ka-band stacked patch antenna for CubeSat applications, considering the unique environmental and thermal conditions of space (p. 4)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a Ka-band stacked patch antenna be designed to meet the multiphysics constraints of CubeSat missions? (p. 1); How can a stacked patch antenna be optimized for CubeSat applications in the Ka-band? (p. 8); What are the thermal and mechanical performance characteristics of the optimized antenna in a LEO environment? (p. 8); How can the antenna design be optimized to meet the operational requirements in Ka-band for CubeSat applications? (p. 4); Not mentioned; What is the impact of thermal and mechanical stresses on the performance of the antenna? (p. 1); What are the thermal and mechanical stresses that the antenna will experience in a LEO mission, and how can they be mitigated? (p. 7)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm, finite difference time domain (FDTD) simulations, and heat transfer analysis (pp. 4-7)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms other designs in bandwidth and gain (p. 10)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Broadside radiation with stable gain over frequency (p. 10)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Ka-band stacked patch antenna (p. 4)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT/duroid 5880 (εr = 2.2, tan δ = 0.001, h = 0.254 mm) (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Single feed point centered on an axis and shifted towards the orthogonal edge (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.frequency_b: Ka-band (26–34.7 GHz for down- and uplink) (p. 1)

gen.conclusions: The reconfigurable circularly polarized patch antenna is a viable solution for CubeSat applications, offering improved performance and integration capabilities (p. 157)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Comparison of simulation results with measurement data (p. 162)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Anechoic chamber for measurements (p. 162); HFSS simulation software (p. 160); HFSS FEM method and QNM package for simulation (p. 161)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and simulation of a reconfigurable circularly polarized patch antenna (p. 157)
gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design and testing of a circularly polarized patch antenna (p. 161)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The antenna achieved a maximum gain of 10 dBic at 2.45 GHz (p. 162); The axial ratio was 0.93 dB at 2.45 GHz (p. 163); The axial ratio is 1.5 dB at the same frequency (p. 157); The impedance bandwidth was 33.4% for a reflection coefficient of -10 dB (p. 163); The maximum gain is 6.1 dBi at a central frequency of 2.35 GHz (p. 157); The reflection coefficient is inferior to -10 dB (p. 157); The antenna design shows a wide impedance bandwidth of 33.33% from 1.9 GHz to 2.66 GHz (p. 157)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The measured and simulated results were similar, with minor differences in the radiation pattern due to measurement limitations (p. 163); The antenna can be integrated into one side of a 1U CubeSat with dimensions 76 mm x 76 mm x 3 mm (p. 157); The antenna showed a wide impedance bandwidth of 33.4% (p. 163)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna design meets the requirements for CubeSat applications, providing a wide impedance bandwidth, high gain, and reconfigurable circular polarization, which enhances communication efficiency (p. 157)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Simulation | description: The results are based on simulation and may differ from actual performance in real-world conditions (p. 157); limitation_type: Measurement | description: Differences in the measured radiation pattern compared to simulations due to the limitations of the anechoic chamber (p. 163)
gen.metadata.keywords: hybrid coupler; Reconfigurable antenna; circular polarization; Circular polarization; antenna design; CubeSat; Shorted annular ring antenna
gen.metadata.authors: Puerto-Leguizamón, G. A.; Méndez, D.R.; Suárez-Fajardo, C. A.; Puerto-Leguizamón, G.A.; Suárez-Fajardo, C.A.; Pineda, A.; Pineda-Rodríguez, A.; Méndez-Marín, D. R.
gen.metadata.title: Diseño de una antena de parche con geometría en anillo circular cortocircuitado para satélites CubeSat 1U
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a reconfigurable circularly polarized patch antenna for CubeSat applications that can be integrated into one side of a 1U CubeSat (p. 157)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Evaluate the performance of the antenna in terms of reflection coefficient and gain (p. 157); Optimize the antenna's impedance bandwidth, gain, and axial ratio (p. 157); Obtain an axial ratio of 0.93 dB at the same frequency (p. 163); Achieve a 33.4% impedance bandwidth for a reflection coefficient of -10 dB (p. 163); Achieve a maximum gain of 10 dBic at the central frequency of 2.45 GHz (p. 163)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Exploration of other reconfigurable antenna designs for CubeSat applications (p. 157); Investigation of the antenna's performance in different environmental conditions (p. 157); Investigate the performance of the antenna in different CubeSat configurations (p. 163)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the 90° hybrid coupler for improved performance and reconfigurable polarization (p. 163); Further testing and validation of the antenna design in real-world CubeSat applications (p. 157)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for efficient communication systems in CubeSat satellites, particularly in the VHF/UHF bands, which have low bit rates and linear polarization, and the exploration of higher frequency bands for better performance (p. 158)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What is the performance of the designed antenna in terms of gain, axial ratio, and bandwidth? (p. 163); How can the size and performance of patch antennas be optimized for CubeSat applications? (p. 158); What are the benefits of using circular polarization and reconfigurable rotation sense in CubeSat antennas? (p. 158); How can a circularly polarized patch antenna be designed to fit within the space constraints of a CubeSat 1U? (p. 163)

esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Not mentioned
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Shorted annular ring (SAR) antenna with circular polarization and reconfigurable sense of rotation (p. 157)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Two terminals metálicos that part from the ports of the 90° hybrid coupler (p. 159)

gen.conclusions: The designed antenna achieves a maximum gain of 6.04 dB at 2.44 GHz and an axial ratio bandwidth of 48.56 MHz (2%) at the same frequency. The hybrid coupler allows reconfigurable rotation direction from RHCP to LHCP and vice versa (p. 8)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Comparison of measured and simulated results for S11, S12, gain, and radiation pattern (p. 6-7)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Anechoic chamber (p. 7); Vector Network Analyzer (VNA) Rohde&Schwartz ZVL13 for impedance characterization (p. 3); Axial ratio measurement using a rotating dipole (p. 3); Gain measurement using the absolute gain method with three antennas (p. 3); Vector Network Analyzer (VNA) Rohde&Schwartz ZVL13 (p. 6)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and simulation of a circular microstrip patch antenna with a hybrid quadrature coupler (pp. 2-3)
gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design and characterization of a short-circuited patch antenna (p. 6)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: Achieved a maximum gain of 6.04 dB at 2.44 GHz (p. 7); Achieved an axial ratio bandwidth of 48.56 MHz (2%) at 2.44 GHz (p. 7); Impedance bandwidth of 27.44% from 2.295GHz to 3.025GHz at 2.44GHz (p. 1); Axial ratio bandwidth of 48.56MHz (2%) at 2.44GHz (p. 1); Maximum gain of 6.04dBi at 2.44GHz (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The antenna is suitable for attachment to one face of a CubeSat 1U (p. 1); Measured impedance bandwidth of 27.44% for S11 < -10 dB in the range of 2.295 GHz to 3.025 GHz (p. 7); Measured coupling bandwidth of 50 MHz (2.05%) at 2.44 GHz (p. 6)
gen.discussion: The design of the short-circuited patch antenna with a 90° hybrid coupler achieves the desired performance for CubeSat 1U applications, with good agreement between measured and simulated results (p. 7-8)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study is specific to the design and performance of a single antenna design (p. 3); limitation_type: Measurement environment | description: Differences in measured and simulated radiation patterns attributed to limitations in the anechoic chamber and support mechanisms (p. 7)
gen.metadata.keywords: circular polarization; antena reconfigurable; reconfigurable; aplicación satelital; polarización circular; antenna; CubeSat; antena de parche circular

gen.metadata.title: Antena de Parche Cortocircuitado con Polarización Circular y Sentido de Giro Reconfigurable para Aplicaciones en Satélites de Reducido Tamaño
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and characterize a circular microstrip patch antenna with reconfigurable circular polarization for small satellites (CubeSat 1U) (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve an axial ratio bandwidth of 48.56 MHz (2%) at 2.44 GHz (p. 7); Achieve an axial ratio bandwidth of 48.56MHz (2%) (p. 1); Achieve a maximum gain of 6.04dBi (p. 1); Achieve a maximum gain of 6.04 dB at 2.44 GHz (p. 7); Achieve an impedance bandwidth of 27.44% (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the impact of different hybrid couplers on antenna performance (p. 8); Explore further optimization techniques to enhance performance (p. 3)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the antenna design into CubeSat 1U for improved communication performance (p. 3); Use the hybrid coupler for reconfigurable rotation direction in CubeSat applications (p. 8)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Design of a short-circuited patch antenna with circular polarization and reconfigurable rotation direction for CubeSat 1U applications (p. 6)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can the bandwidth and gain of the antenna be optimized for CubeSat applications? (p. 6); What is the impact of the hybrid coupler on the antenna's performance? (p. 6); What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna design? (p. 1); How can a circular microstrip patch antenna be designed to achieve reconfigurable circular polarization? (p. 1)

esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Not mentioned

esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: 90° hybrid coupler feeding the antenna at two points (p. 6)

gen.conclusions: A low-profile S-band CubeSat antenna with broadband CP radiation has been successfully designed and tested. The antenna can be realized with different substrates and is compatible with any CubeSat standard structure (p. 9)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Simulation results and experimental measurements (p. 5)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Simulation software (Altair FEKO) (p. 7); Vector network analyzer (Keysight N5244A PNA-X) for impedance measurement (p. 5); ANSYS Electronics Desktop for simulation (p. 2); Anechoic chamber for measurements (p. 8); Tapered anechoic chamber for far-field radiation measurement (p. 5)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Experimental and simulation-based (pp. 2-3)
gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design and performance evaluation of a single-feed slotted-patch antenna loaded with a metasurface (p. 7)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: Achieved an axial ratio < 3 dB bandwidth of 15.23% (1.94-2.26 GHz) (p. 5); The antenna achieved good broadside RHCP radiation with a symmetric profile, high F-B ratio, and high radiation efficiency (p. 8); The proposed antenna achieved a |S11| < −10 dB bandwidth of 24.64% (1.85-2.37 GHz) (p. 8); The broadside realized gain was 5.6 to 6.7 dBic (p. 8); Achieved a broadside realized gain of 5.6 to 6.7 dBic (p. 5); Achieved a |S11| < −10 dB bandwidth of 24.64% (1.85-2.37 GHz) (p. 5); The axial ratio (AR) < 3 dB bandwidth was 15.23% (1.94-2.26 GHz) (p. 8)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: Good broadside right-hand circularly polarized (RHCP) radiation with symmetric pattern, high front-to-back ratio, and high radiation efficiency (p. 1); The estimated measured radiation efficiency was >70% (p. 8); The HPBWs were 72° and 64° at 2.0 GHz, and 64° and 66° at 2.22 GHz (p. 8); The measured F-B ratio was 19.0 dB at 2.0 GHz and 17.0 dB at 2.22 GHz (p. 8)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna design offers a low-profile, broadband, and circularly polarized solution for CubeSat applications, with advantages of simple configuration, stable radiation, and easy fabrication (p. 9)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Radiation efficiency | description: The antenna design on low-cost FR4 substrate suffers a radiation efficiency of 74% to 79% (p. 5); limitation_type: Measurement limitations | description: The measured radiation efficiency could not be directly measured due to the function limitation of the anechoic chamber (p. 8)
gen.metadata.keywords: circular polarization; circularly polarized; extra resonance; slotted-patch antenna; CubeSat; metasurface; surface wave; S-band; slotted patch

gen.metadata.title: Single-feed slotted-patch antenna loaded with metasurface for CubeSat applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a low-profile, single-feed, slotted-patch antenna loaded with metasurface for S-band CubeSat applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve broadband circularly polarized radiation (p. 1); Achieve a broad bandwidth for S11 and axial ratio (p. 7); Enhance broadside gain and radiation efficiency (p. 2); Ensure high radiation efficiency and symmetric radiation pattern (p. 7)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the antenna with different substrates and in different CubeSat configurations (p. 9); Investigate the performance of the antenna in different CubeSat configurations (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the proposed antenna design in CubeSat applications for improved performance (p. 9); Use higher-quality substrates to improve radiation efficiency (p. 5)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Design challenges for CubeSat antennas include compact size, lightweight, mechanically robust structure, broadband, efficiency, stable radiation, and easy integration (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a low-profile, broadband, and circularly polarized antenna be designed for CubeSat applications? (p. 7); What are the performance enhancements of the proposed antenna compared to conventional designs? (p. 2); How can a single-feed slotted-patch antenna loaded with metasurface achieve broadband circularly polarized radiation for S-band CubeSat applications? (p. 1)

esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Good broadside right-hand circularly polarized (RHCP) radiation with symmetric pattern, high front-to-back ratio, and high radiation efficiency (p. 5)

gen.conclusions: The high-gain, circularly polarized X-band microstrip patch antenna designed for CubeSat applications meets the design requirements. The antenna gain is 11.72 dBi, the spatial axial ratio is 1.4 dB, and the 3 dB ARBW is 250 MHz. The design is simple, low-profile, and highly compatible with CubeSat platforms (p. 16)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Simulation results using Altair FEKO, measurement results using VNA and anechoic chamber (p. 12)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Helical antennas for circular polarization qualification (p. 13); CST Studio Suite 2019 for simulation (p. 6); Measurement in an anechoic chamber (p. 3); Not mentioned; Anechoic chamber for far-field radiation pattern measurement (p. 12); Vector Network Analyzer (VNA) for return loss measurement (p. 12)
gen.detailed_methodology.population_cont: X-band microstrip patch antenna for CubeSat applications (p. 1)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Experimental and simulation-based (pp. 10-13)
gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design and performance evaluation of a novel antenna (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The 3 dB ARBW is approximately 250 MHz (p. 16); Not mentioned; Measured axial ratio (AR) of around 1.4 dB at 8.483 GHz (p. 1); Measured gain of around 11.7 dBi at 8.483 GHz (p. 1); The antenna gain is around 11.72 dBi at 8.483 GHz (p. 16); The spatial axial ratio is about 1.4 dB at 8.483 GHz (p. 16)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: Total antenna efficiency exceeding 90% (p. 1); The measured −10 dB operational bandwidth is around 900 MHz (p. 13); The antenna efficiency is 95% (p. 15); Not mentioned; The measured far-field radiation patterns have good agreement with the simulation results (p. 13)
gen.discussion: The design balances high gain, circular polarization, simplicity, and robustness, making it suitable for CubeSat applications. The EBG structure significantly enhances the antenna performance by suppressing surface waves and improving radiation efficiency (pp. 1-6)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Surface area and height constraints | description: The design must fit within the 10 cm × 10 cm surface area and not exceed 6.5 mm in height, which limits the complexity of the antenna (p. 5); limitation_type: Manufacturing | description: Discrepancies in the antenna manufacturing process can affect the measured return loss values (p. 13); limitation_type: Not mentioned | description: Not mentioned

gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a high-gain, circularly polarized X-band microstrip patch antenna for CubeSat applications using an EBG structure (p. 1)

gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The 36-element antenna array achieves a high LHCP gain of 20.1 dB at 10.4 GHz with good cross-polar isolation of -18 dB (p. 4); The array presents a -3 dB AR bandwidth of 3.8% and a -10 dB impedance bandwidth of 21% (p. 4); The -3 dB gain bandwidth of the array is 38.4%, maintaining high gain performance over the X-band (p. 5)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The presence of the CubeSat body increases the cross-polar components by 7 dB in the principal planes, but they remain below -18 dB (p. 4); The side lobe levels (SLLs) in the principal planes stay below -14 dB from the maximum gain (p. 4)
gen.discussion: The proposed high gain CP microstrip patch antenna array is suitable for high-data rate downlink CubeSat communications, greatly expanding the current CubeSat capabilities (p. 5)

gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Comparison of simulated and experimental results using statistical metrics (p. 96)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: CST Microwave Studio EM Simulator for simulations (p. 3); Anechoic chamber (p. 96); Simulation software (Altair FEKO) (p. 96); Network analyzer (ZNLE6, Rohde&Schwarz) (p. 96)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Experimental and simulation-based (pp. 94-97)
gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design and performance evaluation of a broadband CP corner-truncated microstrip antenna with irregularly hexagonal AMC (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The simulated ARBW is 19.3% (2.24 – 2.72 GHz) and the experimental ARBW is 29.4% (2.03 – 2.73 GHz) (p. 96); The proposed antenna achieves a simulated IBW of 50.9% (1.86 – 3.13 GHz) and an experimental IBW of 42.42% (1.95 – 3.0 GHz) (p. 96); The maximum simulated gain is 9.92 dBic and the maximum experimental gain is 10.22 dBic (p. 96); The maximum simulated gain was 10.22 dBic (p. 4); The proposed antenna achieved a simulated IBW of 50.9% (1.86 – 3.13 GHz) and ARBW of 19.3% (2.24 – 2.72 GHz) (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The experimental XP levels at 2.45 GHz are below -15.62 dB in both the xz and yz planes (p. 97); The measured IBW and ARBW were 42.42% (1.95 – 3.0 GHz) and 29.4% (2.03 – 2.73 GHz), with a maximum gain of 8.6 dBic (p. 1); The experimental HPBW are 64° and 54° for the xz and yz planes, respectively (p. 97); The experimental F/B ratios are less than 29.67 dB in both planes (p. 97); The experimental AR beamwidth are 200° and 85° for the xz and yz planes, respectively (p. 97)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna scheme is suitable for the WLAN frequency band and other 2.45 GHz wireless communication technologies. The irregularly hexagonal AMC array enhances ARBW and antenna gain, while the tri-section meandering feedline improves impedance matching and IBW (pp. 97-98)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study is specific to 2.45 GHz WLAN applications and may not be directly applicable to other frequency bands (p. 1); limitation_type: Manufacturing complexity | description: The irregularly hexagonal AMC array may pose challenges in terms of manufacturing complexity and high cost (p. 98); limitation_type: Physical dimensions | description: The physical dimensions of the antenna scheme might not be compact enough for certain applications (p. 98); limitation_type: Integration challenges | description: Integrating the antenna with existing wireless communication systems and/or devices could pose challenges in terms of compatibility and integration optimizations (p. 98)

gen.metadata.authors: Monai Krairiksh; Titipong Lertwiriyaprapa; Pisit Janpangngern; S. Dentri; P. Wichaidit; Chuwong Phongcharoenpanich; P. Janpangngernetal.; Sitthichai Dentri; Purichaya Wichaidit
gen.metadata.title: Compact broadband CP corner-truncated microstrip antenna with irregularly hexagonal AMC for 2.45 GHz WLAN applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To propose a compact broadband circularly polarized (CP) corner-truncated microstrip antenna with irregularly hexagonal artificial magnetic conductor (AMC) for 2.45 GHz WLAN applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Enhance the axial ratio bandwidth (ARBW) and antenna gain using a 5 × 5 irregularly hexagonal AMC array (p. 1); Compare the proposed antenna with existing designs (p. 98); Improve the impedance bandwidth (IBW) using a tri-section meandering feedline (p. 1); Evaluate the performance of the antenna in terms of IBW, ARBW, and gain (p. 98)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the proposed antenna in other frequency bands (p. 1); Experimentally implement the antenna scheme with wireless communication systems and/or devices (p. 98)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Miniaturize the antenna scheme for more diverse applications (p. 98); Simplify the AMC array fabrication to reduce manufacturing complexity and cost (p. 98); Use the proposed antenna design for 2.45 GHz WLAN applications (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Most WLAN CP antennas have narrow impedance bandwidth, resulting in low transmission rates and failure to cover the desired frequency band. Narrow-bandwidth CP antennas often encounter installation challenges due to frequency shift, especially in small rooms with limited space where the antenna needs to be mounted on the wall (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What design modifications can enhance the performance of CP antennas in terms of gain, bandwidth, and circular polarization? (p. 1); What is the impact of the tri-section meandering feedline on impedance matching and IBW? (p. 98); How can the corner-truncated radiating microstrip patch and irregularly hexagonal AMC array be used to enhance ARBW and antenna gain? (p. 98); How can the impedance bandwidth (IBW) and axial ratio bandwidth (ARBW) of CP antennas be improved for 2.45 GHz WLAN applications? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.performance_metri: ['Gain', 'Bandwidth', 'Return Loss', 'VSWR', 'Radiation Pattern', 'Axial Ratio Bandwidth', 'HPBW', 'AR Beamwidth', 'XP Level', 'F/B Ratio'] (p. 96)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: CST Microwave Studio EM Simulator (p. 3)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The proposed antenna achieves higher unidirectional antenna gain and wider bandwidth compared to existing designs (p. 97)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Broadband CP corner-truncated microstrip antenna with irregularly hexagonal AMC (p. 94)

gen.conclusions: The proposed antenna system, which demonstrates excellent performance, high stability, and reliability, as well as low-profile, compact dimensions, can be applied to similar CubeSat platforms (p. 5)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Comparison of simulated and measured results (p. 4)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Agilent network analyzer (E5071C) for return loss measurement (p. 4); In-house far-field antenna measurement system for gain and radiation pattern measurement (p. 4); HFSS for simulation (p. 2); Measurement equipment (anechoic chamber) (p. 5); Simulation software (Altair FEKO) (p. 5)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design, simulation, and measurement of a dual-feed, L/S-dual-band-stacked, CP patch antenna system (p. 5)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: An HPBW of more than 80° is obtained for both bands (p. 5); The return loss for both frequency bands is below -15 dB in the desired frequencies (p. 5); The peak gain for the lower band is 5.4 dBi on the broadside, and for the upper band, it is 6 dBi (p. 4); The measured axial ratio is better than 2 dB for both operating frequency bands (p. 4); The measured return loss is well below –15 dB for both frequency bands (p. 4); The AR is well below 3 dB for both bands (p. 5); Excellent RHCP characteristics are observed (p. 5)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: There is a frequency shift between the simulated results and the measured results for both bands, especially for the upper band (p. 5); The measured half-power beamwidth (HPBW) is about 89° for the lower band and 83° for the upper band (p. 4)
gen.discussion: The antenna system demonstrates excellent performance, high stability, and reliability, as well as low-profile, compact dimensions, making it suitable for similar CubeSat platforms (p. 5)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Testing environment | description: Experiments were conducted without the spacecraft body, which might affect the antenna system’s performance (p. 4); limitation_type: Frequency shift | description: There is a frequency shift between the simulated results and the measured results for both bands, especially for the upper band (p. 5)
gen.metadata.keywords: circular polarization; circularly polarized; patch antenna; CubeSat; dual-band; low profile

gen.metadata.title: A Dual-Feed, L/S-Dual-Band-Stacked, CP Patch Antenna System for 3U CubeSat
gen.objectives.main_objective: To develop a dual-feed, L/S-dual-band-stacked, circularly polarized patch antenna system for a 3U CubeSat (p. 2)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Design and optimize the antenna and feeding network (p. 2); Maintain high stability and reliability (p. 5); Achieve a low profile of 11 mm (p. 5); Fabricate and measure the prototype (p. 3); Ensure excellent right-hand CP (RHCP) characteristics (p. 5); Obtain an HPBW of more than 80° for both bands (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Conduct further testing with the spacecraft body to validate performance (p. 4); Not mentioned
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the designed antenna system into CubeSats for high-data-rate communication (p. 4); Design the antenna in a slightly lower frequency and adjust it to the desired frequency by cutting the four stubs shorter during the experiment (p. 5)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for high-data-rate communication systems in CubeSats, which are constrained by size and weight, and the challenges of multiple-antenna design (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a dual-feed, L/S-dual-band-stacked, circularly polarized patch antenna be designed for CubeSats? (p. 2); How can a dual-feed, L/S-dual-band-stacked, CP patch antenna system be designed for 3U CubeSats? (p. 5); What are the performance metrics of the designed antenna? (p. 4)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: An in-house far-field antenna measurement system and an Agilent network analyzer (E5071C) (p. 4)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 5)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Not mentioned
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Dual-feed, L/S-dual-band-stacked, circularly polarized patch antenna (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT/duroid 5880 (εr = 2.2, tan δ = 0.0009, h = 0.787 mm) (p. 3)
